PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the Australian National Flag.
2.We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Faulkner (from 14 citizens) and Senator Hill (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Newman (from 117 citizens) and Senator Reid (from 10 citizens).

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

1. Many Australians agree with the stated aim of the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship, namely to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the nation's national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push.
2. We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship continue to be tenable at the Institute of Advanced Studies of ANU and CSIRO.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women and Work
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) That Australia has one of the most highly sex segregated workforces of any OECD country;
(2) That after nine years of Labor Government, women on average still earn only 83 per cent of equivalent male wages;
(3) That women suffer disproportionately from unemployment, making up 75 per cent of discouraged job seekers;
(4) That inflexible working hours and a lack of sufficient childcare facilities are detrimental to women in the workforce;
(5) That the economic platforms of both the Government and the Opposition fail to address these gender issues adequately.

Wherefore your Petitioners request that the parliament should recognise the significance of these facts, immediately take appropriate action to remedy the disadvantages suffered by women in economic life, and ensure that the power to make economic decisions affecting women is placed in women's hands.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Waste
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That residents of Pontypool, Wales, have been exposed to unreasonable health risks by the incineration in their environment of toxic waste products including polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs);

That it is unacceptable for the Australian Government to permit the Western Australian Government to dispose of such toxic waste products by exporting them to Pontypool, Liverpool, or other overseas venues;
That it behoves Australian governments to compel the producers of such waste products to meet the costs of disposal in Australia.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worst extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Burma
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of Tasmania draws to the attention of the Senate that on the 18th September 1988, the military force in Burma known as SLORC demonstrated its callous disregard of the welfare and rights of Burmese citizens in killing approximately 4,000 innocent people.

Despite international pressure and elections that should have seen democracy restored to the country, the State Law and Order Restoration Council continues to deny the people of Burma their human rights and carries out brutal military offensives against all ethnic minorities.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will call on the Australian Government to continue to press in the United Nations for an embargo on the sale of arms to Myanmar (Burma) until the offensive against ethnic minorities cease and the democratically elected government is allowed to take office.

PETITION.TITLE: Pay Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners respectfully request that the Broadcasting Services Bill which will control Television and Pay Television, will:
prohibit all excessively violent programs
prohibit indecent and obscene programs

PETITION.PARA: prohibit blasphemous programs which denigrate religious faith or belief
establish strict legally enforceable standards for programs and transmission times
ensure that films are judged not as a whole, but in all parts
ensure genuine consumer consultation, so that parents can have access to program criteria information, and input into decision-making for their home environment

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Practices Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned request that Sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act be repealed without delay.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Chemicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners request that the Parliament supports a Bill for an Act to provide for a community right to know all information pertaining to industrial use, manufacture, transport, storage, recycling and handling of toxic chemicals, introduced into the Senate by Senator Janet Powell.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Migrant Education Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Adult Migrant Education Program (AMEP), including Workplace English Language and Literacy, must continue as a fully Government funded educational program with equality of access for all non-English speaking permanent residents.
We call on the Federal Government not to implement fees for adult English as a Second Language (ESL) programs. Many migrants who are not exempt cannot afford to pay fees.
We call on the Federal Government to remove the limit of 510 hours tuition, because most students need a minimum of 900 hours of English for work of further study.

We call on the Federal Government to restore access to all migrants and refugees regardless of length of residence in Australia and employment status, and to provide continuing funding for all adult ESL Programs to public education institutions, in particular AMES.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioners: Shares
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
The legislation passed in December 1992 to count the increases in the value of shares held by pensioners as income, even if the shares are never sold to realise the gain:
(1) Is unjust.
(2) Has its most detrimental effect on pensioners with small holdings.
(3) Only affects Australian Stock Exchange listed shares.
(4) Discourages small scale investment in Australian companies.
Your Petitioners request that the amendments in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (no 3) 1992 relating to unrealised capital gains on shares should be repealed.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Beirut: Australian Embassy
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the under-signed shows;
We, the under-signed express our concerns about the continued closure of the Australian Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon.

Accordingly in view of the deprivation caused by all business with the Australian Embassy in having to be conducted out-side of Lebanon and in view of the large number of over 800,000 Lebanese Australians living in Australia and others in Lebanon who feel deserted by the Australian Government and the costs involved and the frustrations caused by the absence of the Australian Embassy from Beirut.
We call on the Federal Government of Australia to immediately re-open the Australian Embassy in Lebanon.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Influenza Vaccine
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

We wish to draw your attention to the urgent need for funding for the recently released Haemophilus Influenzae Type B (HiB) vaccine. HiB disease causes suffering, death and permanent disability in babies and young children.

The HiB vaccine is recommended by the NH&MRC for all babies and children from the ages of 2 months to 5 years. It is to be added to the routine immunization schedule and is the first significant addition since measles in 1968. All other routine vaccinations are free.

The HiB vaccine is presently only available to those who can afford to pay for it on a user pays basis. This will effectively result in many babies and children remaining at risk of contracting the HiB disease. This is a social justice issue.
We believe it is inappropriate to add this vaccine to the recommended schedule when it is unfunded or only partially funded.
We are asking that this vaccine be made accessible to all babies and children from 2 months to 5 years of age. Please fully fund this new HiB vaccine for all Australian children.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Parliament: Citizenship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1That we the undersigned are citizens of Australia, whether by naturalisation or by birth.
2That we are loyal to Australia and to the flag that flies over Australian soil and waters.
3That each one of us is of ethnic parentage or ancestry.
4That we are concerned by the recent High Court of Australia judgement that people subject to the rights of another nation cannot sit in the Australian Parliament.
5That we believe that anyone born in Australia is first and foremost an Australian and entitled to all the rights and privileges of same unless they publically renounce such rights.
6That we believe that anyone who has sworn allegiance to our nation and become naturalised is an Australian entitled to all rights and privileges of being same.
7And that we therefore urge this Senate to urgently take measures to ensure the rights and privileges that have been removed by the High Court.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the food labelling laws currently in use in Australia are inadequate for consumers to identify quickly and easily where a product is made, where the ingredients used originate and whether the company is Australian.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: support the Bill proposed by Australian Democrat Senator Meg Lees to revamp Australia's food labelling laws.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that funding for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has already been reduced by some $120 million. Any further reduction would unacceptably compromise the quality of service and endanger the independence of our national broadcaster and we ask that no further reductions in funding be agreed to by the Senate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)welcomes a variety of processes to prepare options papers to enable the people of Australia and the Parliament to consider the minimum constitutional changes necessary to achieve a viable federal republic of Australia, while maintaining the effect of our present conventions and principles of government;
(b)considers that the terms of reference for these options papers should address:

TAB.TAB: (i)the option to remove all references to the monarch in the Constitution,

(ii)the option to establish a new office of Head of State and the need to consider what that office may be called, including the possible retention of the name Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia,
(iii)the provisions for the appointment and termination of the appointment of the Head of State, including the option of election by the two Houses of the Parliament on nomination by the Government,
(iv)how the powers of the new Head of State can be made subject to the same conventions and principles which apply to the powers of the Governor-General,
(v)the implications for the States, including full consultations with the States about these implications, and
(vi)the nature of amendments to the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia required to implement options;

PARA.TAB: (c)believes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)all of the findings of these processes remain entirely subject to full and open discussion and debate by the people of Australia and the Parliament before proceeding to referenda, and
(ii)any referenda on this matter should not be held in conjunction with a parliamentary election or any other referenda;

PARA.TAB: (d)expresses the view that a significant date for implementation of these minimum constitutional changes, if supported, would be 1 January 2001; and
(e)accordingly, urges sound and unhurried preparation and consideration of the various options papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Lees and on my own behalf, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act (No. 3) 1992, and the Social Security Act 1991 and for related purposes.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)that the horrific current account deficit of $2.1 billion recorded for March 1993,
(ii)that this is the highest deficit figure for more than 3 years,
(iii)that the cumulative deficit for 1992-93 is 32 per cent higher than for the comparable period in 1991-92,
(iv)that the `recession we had to have' was a deliberate policy instrument aimed at tackling the then-burgeoning current account deficit in 1989-90,
(v)that this recession which produced one million unemployed has clearly failed to `fix' this problem,
(vi)that the Government's budgetary position since 1989-90 has collapsed by more than $30 billion, the greatest collapse in Australia's history,
(vii)that the massive borrowings required to fund the Budget deficit are largely responsible for the present national savings erosion, and
(viii)that the underlying problems in Australia of spending more than we can afford, low investment, no savings and rising debts are all expressed through the current account deficit; and

PARA.TAB: (b)expresses its grave concern that the Government's policies over the past decade, and in particular during the past five years and the recession, have only added massive unemployment and its associated costs to Australia's underlying problems, without solving anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the commitment to peace and disarmament of 800 people from all over Australia who gathered in peaceful protest at the Nurrungar defence facility over Easter 1993, and
(ii)the Government's recently released foreign policy priorities, which include working actively for further arms control and disarmament measures; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government to:

TAB.TAB: (i)terminate the agreement binding its defence policy to that of the United States of America through facilities such as Nurrungar and Pine Gap, and

(ii)demonstrate its foreign policy independence by working towards the establishment of an international arms control body which would use Nurrungar and Pine Gap as part of a multilateral arms and weapons testing monitoring regime.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the March 1993 current account deficit of $2.1 billion is further evidence of how fragile our economy is,
(ii)the increase in imports of 16 per cent and the fall in exports of 7 per cent is particularly disturbing,
(iii)Australia's cumulative current account deficit for the nine months of the 1992-93 financial year is now $11.9 billion, an increase from $9 billion at the same stage in 1992,
(iv)the current drought and the wool crisis will cause escalating problems in our balance of payments, and
(v)the Government's program, as outlined in the opening speech of His Excellency the Governor-General on 4 May 1992, completely avoided the issue of our rising current account deficit; and

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns the Labor Government for its repeated failures to address this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that the week beginning 2 May 1993:

TAB.TAB: (i)marks Law Week throughout Australia, and
(ii)is an appropriate time for practitioners, judges and politicians to consider the rising cost of justice which has put the legal system beyond the reach of most Australians; and

PARA.TAB: (b)urges consideration of measures to provide access to the legal system on a basis of genuine equality, including the following:

TAB.TAB: (i)independent tribunals with consumer representation to fix lawyers fees and court charges,
(ii)independent complaints tribunal for the legal profession and for judges to deal with allegations of misconduct and bias,
(iii)increased legal aid funding, with all interest from solicitors trust funds to go to Legal Aid,
(iv)supervision of the legal profession by the Trade Practices Commission,
(v)allowing the advertising of all fees by barristers and solicitors,
(vi)abolition of Queen's Counsel appointments,
(vii)legislation in simple English,
(viii)increased case management by judges, and
(ix)comprehensive mediation programs to provide an alternative to the court process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)recognises that on the very day that this Government celebrated its return to office the empty promises which it used to be re-elected were highlighted by the worst balance of payments figures in more than 3 years;
(b)acknowledges that a fall in exports of 7 per cent coupled with a rise in imports of 16 per cent has caused a blowout of Australia's current account deficit by 150 per cent;

(c)condemns the Government for its continuing failure to offer economic leadership at a time when the most likely outcome of the Government's mismanagement is another balance of payments crisis, which will see Australian business plunge into an interest rate spiral; and
(d)calls upon the Australian people to judge the ability of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his Government to deliver their grandiose election promises over the next 3 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes—
(a)the recently released statistical summary by the Australian Taxation Office of the 1990-91 tax returns which shows continuing declining trends within the economy;
(b) that the statistics reveal:

TAB.TAB: (i)a fall in the number of taxable companies from 160 000 to 152 000, with private companies bearing the brunt of this fall, reducing by more than 6 000,
(ii)that the number of provisional taxpayers fell by 154 000,
(iii)the number of non-provisional taxpayers fell by 80 000, and
(iv)that net tax for 1993 also fell by 2.7 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the level of lead in petrol sold in Australia is very high by the standards of developed countries and that this is having a detrimental effect on the intellectual development of Australian children living in inner city areas and lead smelter towns, and
(ii)the lead level in Australian fuels is up to 30 times higher than that which applies in the United States of America; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government to legislate immediately for a national uniform level of lead in petrol of no more than 0.026 grams per litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate calls upon the Government to convene a committee of eminent Australians to prepare a discussion paper on the strengths and benefits of Australia's current Constitution and its Constitutional Monarchy, which have given our nation unrivalled political stability over the past 92 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)breast cancer remains the leading cause of death in women in Australia, with 2 513 women dying from breast cancer in 1992, and
(ii)breast cancer is now at epidemic proportions, killing about 250 000 women annually in the developed world;

PARA.TAB: (b)deplores the fact that total funding allocated for research into breast cancer in Australia in 1993 is less than $1.5 million, while funding for research into AIDS, by comparison, is almost $10 million annually, despite the fact that five times as many people died from breast cancer; and
(c)calls on the Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)to explain why adequate funds are not being allocated for research into the cause and treatment of breast cancer, and
(ii)to increase funding for research and treatment of breast cancer as a matter of urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Social Security Act 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)condemns the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for establishing an elitist, centralist and statist committee of so-called eminent people to advise on the shape of future options for a republican Australia; and
(b)calls on the Prime Minister:

TAB.TAB: (i)to recognise that the citizens of Australia should be the eminent people in the debate on the way their nation is governed in the future, and
(ii)to abolish the current committee, which is dominated by representatives from Sydney, and establish a committee elected by the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes that thousands of people in rural Australia are suffering a devastating crisis at present caused by the collapse of wool prices and a severe drought in Queensland and northern New South Wales;
(b)condemns the Government for contributing to the hardship felt in the rural sector through its economic mismanagement and engineered recession;
(c)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)with disgust, that the Government has no plan to deal with the crisis, and
(ii)the opening speech on 4 May 1993 by His Excellency the Governor-General;

PARA.TAB: (d)expresses amazement at the lack of comment on the plight of rural Australia in this speech, which included no reference to the current devastating drought; and

TAB.TAB: (i)to stop such defence co-operation and, in particular, to stop providing military training, weapons and equipment to countries where such assistance would be used for suppressing internal political dissent, and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)reports that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) spent $1.3 million on an anti-Coalition propaganda campaign in the lead-up to the Federal Election held on 13 March 1993, and

(d)condemns the Government for this flagrant misuse of funds and abuse of Australian taxpayers, who are already reeling under the economic disasters of the Keating Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

SPEECH.PARA: This motion relates to a range of reforms to Senate procedures. I hope this chamber will see these reforms as part of a package that the Government is bringing on for debate today to improve the processes and procedures of this chamber. I bring in this package in the knowledge—and of course great pleasure on the part of Government senators—that we have seen the Government re-elected with an increased mandate and a real determination to improve the processes and procedures in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: This motion relates to four matters. I doubt that there will be a huge amount of controversy about the first matter dealing with titles of office holders in this chamber, which I know has the strong support of the Deputy President of the Senate, Senator Colston. The Government is absolutely determined to remove the hyphen between the word `Deputy' and the word `President' to improve our Standing Orders. I hope that the Opposition can see its way clear to support that important change, and I look forward to that support.

Another matter that is dealt with relates to the continuation of the office of President. This is basically to remove an anomaly in the Standing Orders which relates to the vacation of office in the event of a serving President not being re-elected. Mr President, I am absolutely delighted in this case that not only can we ensure that the Standing Orders remove any anomaly for the future but—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. As I hear the Parliamentary Secretary, he seems to be debating—
—He is a Minister.
—What is he? Is he a Minister?
—Yes. We are improving, going up market.

—The last Manager of Government Business appointed by those opposite was a Parliamentary Secretary, was he not? Mr President, as I hear the Minister, he seems to be debating the merits of certain changes. As I read the motion, it does not address that issue. The motion is to put these matters on the Notice Paper for the next day of general business. The Manager of Government Business appears to be addressing subject matter other than that which is in his motion. Therefore, I ask for clarification.

—The point raised by Senator Hill is correct, that this debate is only putting this matter back on the Notice Paper. Judging by some of the interjections, I am not so sure that was the understanding of all senators in the chamber, but that is the situation.
—If that is accepted, Mr President, I am more than happy to sit down, and I look forward to the support of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Faulkner) proposed:

(1)That any Senator appointed a parliamentary secretary under the Parliamentary Secretaries Act 1980 may exercise the powers and perform the functions conferred upon ministers by the procedures of the Senate, but may not be asked or answer questions which may be put to ministers under standing order 72(1).
(2)That this order operate as a sessional order.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion deals with the functions of Parliamentary Secretaries. In the last Parliament we allowed certain discretions in relation to one Parliamentary Secretary, Senator McMullan, concerning his responsibilities as Manager of Government Business in the Senate.
—Not only that; he had more than that.

—That is what I am trying to have clarified. It seems to us that the Government is now seeking to expand the role of Parliamentary Secretaries in relation to Senate business to include other Parliamentary Secretaries. No case has been made out for that.

PARA.TAB: The Government is entitled to appoint Parliamentary Secretaries under the relevant Act to do its business but, as far as the Senate is concerned, their role in the Senate will be determined by the Senate. We had this debate before. As I said in relation to Senator McMullan, the case was made out that he should be extended—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all!

—Senator McMullan will get a chance to answer in a minute. The case was made out that he should be extended certain privileges because that made for sensible and better management of the processes of this House. But why should we extend the same powers to Senator Sherry? We look forward to hearing the Government's answer. Why should it be extended in relation to other Parliamentary Secretaries? How is that going to facilitate the good management and conduct of this place?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate that took place when I started as Parliamentary Secretary and, subsequently, the second time around, which led to the final form of words contained in this motion, as I recall it, may well have taken place before I became Manager of Government Business in the Senate. There was a significant period during which I was a Parliamentary Secretary and not Manager of Government Business. It came from discussions that we had which did not relate to my capacity, in particular, as Parliamentary Secretary, but which related to dealing with certain Bills.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the first Bill I dealt with as Parliamentary Secretary, I operated on a fairly constrained interpretation of my rights in that matter. The Opposition raised some concern and said, `This is limiting the debate because you are not participating fully in a way that a Minister would'. I think either Senator Watson or Senator Baume raised some concerns which I thought were right. We undertook some further discussions and then had a subsequent debate in the Parliament.

Certainly, the exercise of these rights as set out in notice of motion No. 7 was indispensable to my conduct of the role of Manager of Government Business, but it was also fundamental to the basic discharge of debate in the Parliament on all those tax Bills and on the other matters of legislation with which I dealt both here and before the various committees of the Parliament, representing Ministers or in my own capacity as a Parliamentary Secretary. For example, the capacity of Senator Sherry to represent the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy before the estimates committee derives from this proposed resolution because the standing orders of the committees operate on the same basis as these Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have 10 Ministers.

—That is right. The House of Representatives has followed the Senate's sensible reform and is operating fundamentally on the same basis. It should do so because it is the most efficient and sensible way to proceed. This reform was not brought in simply because it was a necessary part of the process of a Parliamentary Secretary by coincidence being Manager of Government Business. This is a cross that Senator Watson may have to bear for some years, I regret to say.
—You were the only one on that side who knew anything about tax.

—He will not be dealing with tax matters until I can persuade him that it is such a good idea that he should. The significance of this motion is to enable the efficient conduct of the Senate's business. It makes no difference to the arithmetic of whether things get passed or defeated. It makes no difference to anything other than to enable the Senate's business to flow smoothly.

PARA.TAB: When the sessional order was more constrained than this, it caused problems not so much for us—although also for us—but for the Opposition. This motion is fundamentally consistent—although I cannot say identical because I have not checked the final form—with the procedure in the House of Representatives. As I understand it, it is also consistent with the operation of Parliamentary Secretaries in most parliaments around the world. Furthermore, it is not so much in the interests of the Government but in the interests of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a classic example of the old adage, give them an inch and they will take a mile. There were those of us who objected very strenuously to the precedent being set of a man who was not a Minister with the responsibilities of a Minister being given the trappings of a Minister—let alone the pay of one. There were those of us who saw the use of our Constitution to swear them in as members of the Executive Council, simply because there is no provision to have junior Ministers, as a way of giving de facto pay increases to the favoured ones who dipped out on having a ministry.

PARA.TAB: The point we are discussing here is that, come 1 July, the Government will have only 30 senators in this chamber. Therefore, Ministers will have to carry an extra load because the Government could not attract enough votes to get more senators. There is no reason why we should not examine the proposal to have Ministers from the lower House who are responsible for expenditure attend at estimates committees in the carriage of the debate concerning the proper expenditure of taxpayers' money. That is a much better proposal than having someone, who is merely categorised as a Parliamentary Secretary in order to be given lurks and perks, carrying on as if he or she were truly a Minister.

The bottom line is that if we agree to this sort of motion, we will be complicitous in this charade that the Government is now seeking to perpetuate. We granted Senator McMullan certain status as a singular and isolated example where there was a demonstrated need to grant that particular position.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was the only one who knew anything about finance.

—That is the point. There was a paucity of Ministers on the other side with any knowledge to deal with matters at hand. We agreed to that proposition because he was the Manager of Government Business. The Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) is now seeking to use that one-off example as a precedent for having as many Parliamentary Secretaries as the Government wants.

PARA.TAB: For heaven's sake, there is nothing to prevent the Government having all the Government senators declared Parliamentary Secretaries with the status of Ministers. It makes a mockery and laughing stock of the Government's position of having a so-called small number of people who constitute the Ministry. As there are 40 in the Ministry now, will it be 50 next time and maybe 60 the time after that, with de facto pay increases?

This motion is being brought on in this chamber for the simple reason that there will be only 30 senators on that side. If the Democrats vote with the Government on any particular issue, it will no longer be enough to give it the numbers. The Government will either have to get the concurrence of the Greens or Senator Harradine in order to get legislation passed. We have to acknowledge exactly what this is: it is a grab at a de facto increase in the number of Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recognising that this motion would have this procedure operate as a sessional order, the Australian Democrats will support this motion at this time. I share many of the concerns which have just been raised by Senator Bishop, and I add another one to her list; that is, that in future this could well become a way of undermining the power and the functions of the Senate.
—Why support it?

—On this occasion we have simply one person being replaced by another person. We do not see that as an expansion of the system. But it must not become a process by which arrangements for Parliamentary Secretaries could be expanded. We simply sound this warning to the Government: we would not like to see an arrangement occur whereby Parliamentary Secretaries progressively take up the positions of Ministers of the lower house and the functions of the Senate are thereby undermined. Our support on this occasion is in recognition of the fact that the order would operate as a sessional order only, and our support is contingent on the system not being abused.

—I take up one point that was raised by Senator McMullan. He made it clear that this proposal was to allow Senator Sherry to appear before an estimates committee. That is a compelling argument for rejecting it. I can understand why the Left keeps getting rolled in New South Wales. Poor old Senator Faulkner cannot count. He thinks that, as a result of a reduction in numbers in the Senate, the Government has increased its mandate. We can see why Senator Richardson is playing on a break.
—I will swap you our result for yours.
—That might be a diversion, Senator McMullan, but it does not bear on the truth of what I just said.
—You know our Senate vote went up.

—The Government had the worst vote in Western Australia—38 per cent of the primary vote—since 1977, with one aberration. The number of Ministers in the Senate has been increased from six to 10. I am not opposed to that, but I am opposed to our having to change the Sessional Orders for the purpose of accommodating paybacks to the mates of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Since the number of Ministers that we have in the Senate has gone up from six to 10, I would have thought that we could expect to have at least one Minister attend each of the estimates committees. I argue that the Government should increase the number of estimates committees.

PARA.TAB: Government senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting to hear the giggles and the guffaws from the other side when somebody pleads for greater representation and greater scrutiny of this Government. I would also be embarrassed if I were honourable senators opposite. Estimates Committee A is covered by two Ministers; Estimates Committee B is covered by three Ministers; Estimates Committee C is covered by two Ministers; and Estimates Committees D, E and F are each covered by one Minister. But for some profound reason we need Senator Sherry coming along as the lackey, answering questions in substitute for a Minister.
—On a subject he knows nothing about.

—Absolutely. There is absolutely no justification for it whatsoever. I am sorry the Australian Democrats have left the chamber, because I implore them to support our proposition to reject this proposal. It would mean that the quality of the presentation and representation by the Government at the estimates committees is diminished to the extent that we will not have ministerial representation on each of the committees.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter the debate because there were a couple of inaccuracies in what was said by honourable senators on the other side.
—I see you are wearing a tie.

—Yes, I am wearing a tie. It means that I am a Minister and you are not, Bronwyn. First of all, Senator Bishop mentioned that the Parliamentary Secretaries were given these positions as a way of paying people off. I want to point out that Parliamentary Secretaries do not get any increase in salary at all. In fact, a backbencher who is the chairman of a standing committee would be better off because he or she would get extra money.
—How many additional staff?
—Yes, there are extra staff, because that person is carrying out—
—What about TA?

—Senator Bishop raises TA. We know the frustration of those on the other side. Senator Bishop thinks she is deserving of TA for her business of travelling around Australia getting the numbers to knock off John Hewson. That is what Senator Bishop wants her TA for.
—Order! Minister, you will use the proper titles.
—Mr President, I accept your correction of my remarks. The first matter was a misunderstanding by Senator Bishop about the nature of the pay of a Parliamentary Secretary.

PARA.TAB: The next matter that was raised by the Opposition concerned estimates committees. There is only one Parliamentary Secretary here in the Senate, and that is my colleague Senator Sherry, who is Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I thought it would be to the advantage of senators opposite to have a chance at estimates committee meetings to question the Parliamentary Secretary who obviously has knowledge of the primary industries and energy portfolio. I am sure that Senator Bishop and others would love to be able to get decent information at the estimates committee on which Senator Sherry will be representing the Government.

Senator Bishop would have to admit that, when Senator McMullan was Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, he was able to handle quite excellently at estimate committee meetings all the questions and queries which she and others raised about taxation and finance matters.

The motion moved by Senator Faulkner maintains the status quo that was agreed to by the Senate when Senator McMullan became Parliamentary Secretary before he became Manager of Government Business in the Senate. Those opposite are rewriting history when they reverse that.

I take note of Senator Coulter's remarks that the Democrats want to make sure that this is not a device which would mean that Ministers are not readily available in the chamber. That point is well taken by those on this side of the chamber. Every effort should always be made to have Ministers available in the Senate at the appropriate time to handle not only Question Time but also Bills passing through the Senate and relevant debate. That might not be achievable on every occasion, but Senator Coulter was being quite constructive in raising that point.

Senator Hill is seeking to change the status quo; he wants to change what the Senate has already agreed to. The process already in place has worked well in the past three years, particularly at the estimates committee hearings. I did not see any great angst displayed by senators when Senator McMullan was representing the Treasurer at estimates committee hearings. I did not see people jumping up and down saying that they were not getting the right sort of information. I did not see that from Senator Bishop or from anybody else. Today we are seeing members of the defeated Liberal Party trying to get the angst out of their system due to the frustration that they will be sitting on the other side for the next three years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Manager of Government Business, Senator Faulkner, has moved a motion that would have the effect of allowing the order relating to Parliamentary Secretaries to operate as a sessional order. For those listening, it is important to note that the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: That any Senator who is appointed a parliamentary secretary under the Parliamentary Secretaries Act 1980 may exercise the powers and perform the functions conferred upon Ministers by the procedures of the Senate . . .

These very wide and very significant powers really go to the heart of constitutional issues in terms of the responsibilities of Ministers vis-a-vis other members of parliament, which would include, in the second category, Parliamentary Secretaries. The motion continues:
but may not be asked or answer questions which may be put to Ministers under standing order 72(1).

I believe that we are moving into a very dangerous area. The Labor Government continually wishes to attack our constitution and its limitations. It is always moving at the fringes. As my colleague Senator Bishop said, using pre-metric terms, `Give them an inch and they will take more than a mile'.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the fault was on this side. I might have to share some of that blame because as a shadow Parliamentary Secretary I certainly permitted some dispensation in terms of the complexities of the Income Tax Assessment Act and other relevant matters. Most people in Australia acknowledge the expertise that Senator McMullan brought to this area. He had certain responsibilities and he discharged them remarkably well.

When we remember that income tax issues go to the very hearts and pockets of all Australians, it is very important that such matters be well clarified. We must remember that this Government is attempting to reduce the amount of time spent debating matters. On important matters, including tax matters, the Government can have a cognate debate on half a dozen Bills and give us something like 20 minutes in which to speak.

The Government has increased the number of Ministers in this place. Therefore, there is no need for the sort of dispensation that was given in one particular circumstance to be applied to a generic situation. The Government has a greater number of Ministers and it has a capacity to handle anything that may arise. I believe that this motion, which seeks to have the order operate as a sessional order, should be defeated.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three matters that I wish to deal with in this debate, one of which is the alleged self-interest matter. Firstly, I am sure that the remarks about my appointment as a Parliamentary Secretary being a payback would draw some sort of wry smile from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I can assure honourable senators that there is no payback involved. The Labor Ministry was appointed on merit; it is a great pool of talent. We are fortunate that the electors of Australia recognised that talent and the lack of talent in the Opposition. But certainly in terms of my own approach to matters concerning the leadership of this party, there is absolutely no payback involved at all.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, in terms of the alleged pay increase that Senator Bronwyn Bishop referred to—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I said `lurks and perks'.
—You said `pay increase'.

—Senator Bishop said `pay increase'; and the Hansard will show that. I would like to see the pay increase because when I got my pay slip last week there was certainly no increase. In fact, the reality is that I face a decrease. Except for the Select Committee on Superannuation, which I would hope to conclude as chair—that continues for only another month—it is not anticipated that I would be able to chair any other committees in future in my current position. That means that potentially I am in for a pay decrease, not a pay increase.

PARA.TAB: The third point that I would like to mention relates to my appearance before estimates committees. I believe that I will be appearing before Estimates Committee A, representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean).

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not Senator Cook?

—It may well be that Senator Cook represents that Minister in this place in other respects, certainly during Question Time, but I hope that I will bring some first-hand knowledge in the area of primary industries before that estimates committee—certainly, I suspect, a greater knowledge than Senator Cook. I will be dealing with those issues in much greater detail than Senator Cook. I will be happy to try to answer the very probing questions of those opposite and I look forward to that experience. I would like to reject the contentions of the Opposition in regard to those three points.

—I wish to ask Senator Sherry whether he gets additional staff and how that assists him in his parliamentary duties as a senator for the State of Tasmania. Senator Sherry, do you get some entitlement to VIP aircraft? Do you get some TA?
—Order!
—I ask whether Senator Sherry gets those additional things. What other additional emoluments does he get as the Parliamentary Secretary?
—The title `Honourable'.
—Someone behind me said that he gets the title `Honourable'. I suppose that he needs that bestowed by decree.

PARA.TAB: When Senator McMullan was given this additional power and responsibility it was quite clear that nobody else on the Government side, the Labor Party side, had any idea of finance, tax or anything to do with money; that is fairly clear from some of the silly speeches that we hear from these people about monetary matters. So for the better working of the Senate we allowed Senator McMullan, the only person on the other side who has any knowledge of those sorts of matters, to have those additional responsibilities.

I really rose to make a plea to the Australian Democrats. Typically, they are not in the chamber. The Senate chamber is the place where business should be transacted; it is the Parliament. I wanted to make a point to the Democrats about this issue, but, as usual, they are not here. Yet they will exercise a vote on this matter. They will come here and vote with the Government, so it appears, on these very important matters concerning the running of this chamber, yet they refuse to participate in the debate, or are negligent in participating, even to the extent of not having anyone present in the chamber who might be able to participate in the debate.

The point I want to make to the Democrats—hopefully some of them will read it in Hansard later—is that one argument that is apparently raised in favour of Senator Sherry taking on this position is that he has some expertise in the field of primary industries and energy. If he has, he did not demonstrate it in the last Parliament. There are now 10 Ministers in this chamber. Surely one of them would be able to handle primary industries and energy.

The ministerial representations show that Senator Cook is the representative of the primary industries and energy Minister in this chamber. If I recall correctly, Senator Cook performed this role in the last Parliament for a good part of the three years and in the Parliament before that. So one would have thought that he might have had some experience in those sorts of matters. Certainly the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) considers that he has that experience. That is why he has nominated him to be the representative Minister in the chamber.

I simply ask the Democrats how they can possibly allow this motion to be passed. I can understand their allowing it, as we did, for Senator McMullan, because nobody else on that side had any idea of those financial matters. But there are plenty of Ministers. Senator Cook has to be the nominated one who can handle those matters. I ask the Democrats, if they hear this or happen to read about it in the future, to think about that before they run willy-nilly and lie down to the Government again in the first controversial decision in this new Parliament. I ask them to think about that very seriously and, hopefully, do the right thing rather than what they have indicated they might propose doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to support what Senator Watson had to say about Senator McMullan holding the position of Parliamentary Secretary in the last Parliament. Senator McMullan brought expertise to the tax field, which those opposite certainly lack. Of course, we on this side of the chamber have the best tax expert in this Parliament in Senator Watson. In that case, I believe that the Opposition did the right thing by listening to Senator McMullan; he delivered pretty well in that position. But in this case—I am not very worried about what Senator Sherry does in this chamber—my worry and reason for rising is that, as we have been told today, Senator Sherry will probably chair the estimates committee that deals with the primary industries and energy portfolio.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy President, you would probably be aware that, in the Governor-General's speech—long and boring as it was—no mention was made of primary industries. Mr Deputy President, Queensland, your own State, is in the grip of one of the worst droughts it has ever had.
Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry can laugh as much as he likes at the plight of Queensland, but he does so at his own peril. Queensland is experiencing the worst drought in history. The wool industry is also in the worst situation since the inception of wool growing. The wool industry also was not mentioned in the Governor-General's speech.

PARA.TAB: The ignoring of country areas of Australia in the Governor-General's speech has been continued by having Senator Sherry in a position of responsibility in this area. I believe that Senator Sherry has some good attributes in other areas. I will have to do some research on Senator Sherry and I may find something. Senator Sherry may care to send me his curriculum vitae so that I can find that information.

Senator Sherry will be answering questions relating to primary industry. As Senator West knows, it is a very important industry for the whole of Australia. I have not heard one word in the Senate from Senator Sherry on primary industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right.

—If he has, he can tell me. I cannot remember one occasion when he has spoken on these matters. If he did speak, he did not make an impression. If he has spoken on these matters, I would ask him to send a copy of his remarks to me. I believe it is insulting to the primary industries of Australia to have a Parliamentary Secretary with no expertise in the game whatsoever heading that committee. With regard to Senator McMullan, he did have expertise in the tax field and I respect him for what he did in that area. Of course, he is not in Senator Watson's class.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the Minister on that estimates committee should be Senator Cook.Senator Cook has no background in primary industry matters, but in the six years that he was the responsible Minister and appeared before that committee, because of the good representation on that committee by those on this side of the chamber—Senator Crane and Senator Brownhill; and I suppose I could include myself—Senator Cook started to come to grips with primary industry matters.

Even though Senator Cook is still the Minister representing the Minister for primary industries, we find that Senator Sherry will take over this responsibility. I am sure Senator Sherry has some attributes in other areas; I hope to find out what they are. This appointment is a total insult to the primary industries of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleagues on this motion. I regard it as a particularly worrying motion for a number reasons, not the least of which is that it is the first of quite a series of major changes which the Government is proposing to the Standing Orders of this Parliament. These changes will affect the capacity of Opposition, Independent and Democrat senators to make the Government more accountable for its actions. It is a very bad start for the new Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner). This motion has not been justified in any way whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: In the old Parliament there were 30 Ministers and in the current Parliament there are 32. In the old Parliament there were four Parliamentary Secretaries and in the current Parliament there are 10. There has been a vast explosion in parliamentary secretaryship. It is very interesting to know why this has occurred. I am not aware of any particular reasons which have justified this very substantial increase in the number of Parliamentary Secretaries.

I listened very carefully to what Senator Sherry said. He said he was not there as a pay-off and he reminded us—and I am grateful for that—that he did not vote for the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the leadership challenge; he voted for Mr Hawke. He then said that he was there on merit. One would have to say that, as far as we are concerned, that remains to be proved, to put it nicely.

He then, rather unfortunately—and which, I think, raises some further worries about this whole position—said that he did not receive any lurks and perks, to use an expression used by my colleague Senator Bishop, in relation to this job. I have here a number of pages which are taken from a report by the Remuneration Tribunal and which carefully list all the lurks and perks—

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of them.

—I thank Senator Bishop. They list some of the lurks and perks of the Parliamentary Secretaries. I propose later to seek leave to incorporate that document in Hansard, with Senator Faulkner's permission and the permission of other honourable senators opposite. But let me just read to the Senate how Senator Sherry and the other nine Parliamentary Secretaries are going to benefit from these new positions, which have not been justified in any way whatsoever. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: A Parliamentary Secretary shall be entitled to be reimbursed for expenses of office reasonably and necessarily incurred in respect of his holding, or performing the functions of, an appointment as a Parliamentary Secretary to a Minister of State, up to a maximum amount of—
wait for it—
$7,000 per annum.

So if I were Senator Sherry I would not worry about losing $7,000 as the Chairman of the Select Committee on Superannuation; he is already covered by clause 1 of the parliamentary entitlements. The document goes on to detail travel expenses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Generously.

—And they are generous. Unlike the ordinary backbenchers of parliament, Senator Sherry enjoys a far wider interpretation of his use of travel allowances and, I suspect, if he follows the precedent set by some of his colleagues, they will be very generously used indeed. Let me read out a number of other entitlements that he has. Clause 5 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where, in the view of the Minister to whom a member or senator is Parliamentary Secretary, it is necessary that the spouse of a Parliamentary Secretary should travel in the company of the Parliamentary Secretary at government expense, the additional cost of a double room over single room accommodation shall be added to the maximum amount payable by way of reimbursement of expenses reasonably incurred by a Parliamentary Secretary.
However, it is not as good as it seems, I have to say, as it goes on:
Such additional cost shall be assessed at $10 unless vouched.

I do not know whether Senator Sherry has a spouse, but let me draw his attention to clause 5 when he makes use of those travel allowances which the Prime Minister has generously granted to him. Clause 4 states:

Travelling expenses up to the amounts specified in paragraph 2 shall be payable to a senator or member by way of reimbursement of expenses reasonably incurred for each overnight stay in a place other than his or her home base when that stay is occasioned primarily by official business as a Parliamentary Secretary to a Minister of State, or direct travel to or from such business, provided that if he or she remains within his or her electorate—
lucky Senator Sherry—
he or she must stay at least 100 kilometres from his or her home base.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three hundred bucks a night.

—Senator Bishop has drawn my attention to the fact that Senator Sherry is entitled to $300 a night. It was not correct for Senator Sherry to stand up and say that there are no additional entitlements as a result of his appointment as a Parliamentary Secretary. This Prime Minister, in order to pay off his factional deals and to keep his mates and factions happy, has lifted the number of Parliamentary Secretaries from four to 10. I rather thought that, given the performance of some of them in the last Parliament, four was a bit excessive, but that number has now greatly expanded to 10.

PARA.TAB: I urge Senator Faulkner, who is in his first day as Manager of Government Business in the Senate, to stand up and carefully explain to this chamber just why Senator Sherry should be a Parliamentary Secretary. What will be his duties? Could the Minister clarify and correct, to save Senator Sherry any further embarrassment, the details of his particular entitlements because, as I read them, they are very generous indeed. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the three pages of a report from the Remuneration Tribunal headed, `Parliamentary Secretaries—reimbursement of expenses'.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Determination Number 8 of 1992
PARLIAMENTARY SECRETARIES—REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES

Pursuant to sub-section 7(1A) of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973, the Remuneration Tribunal has inquired into the maximum amounts to be paid out of the public moneys of Australia to Parliamentary Secretaries by way of reimbursement of expenses reasonably incurred by them in respect of their holding, or performing the functions of, appointments as Parliamentary Secretaries to Ministers of State, and determines the maximum amounts as hereunder, with effect from the date of this determination:
Expenses of Office

1.A Parliamentary Secretary shall be entitled to be reimbursed for expenses of office reasonably and necessarily incurred in respect of his holding, or performing the functions of, an appointment as a Parliamentary Secretary to a Minister of State, up to a maximum amount of $7,000 per annum.

The `home base' of a Parliamentary Secretary for the purposes of this determination shall be his or her principal place of residence (and he or she shall identify their principal place of residence to the President in respect of a senator or to the Speaker in respect of a member of the House of Representatives).

4. Travelling expenses up to the amounts specified in paragraph 2 shall be payable to a senator or member by way of reimbursement of expenses reasonably incurred for each overnight stay in a place other than his or her home base when that stay is occasioned primarily by official business as a Parliamentary Secretary to a Minister of State, or direct travel to or from such business, provided that if he or she remains within his or her electorate he or she must stay at least 100 km from his or her home base.

5. Such additional cost shall be assessed at $10 unless vouched.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that everyone on this side of the chamber was overcome by Senator Sherry's modesty when he said that it was not a payback, it was not anything to do with mates; it was all done on merit.
—It is.
—I assure Senator Burns that we are all overcome by Senator Sherry's modesty when he says, `It is all done on merit, even though I say it myself'.
—Well, you should be.
—Burnsie, if it was on merit, you'd have a job.
—Yes, if it were done on merit, Senator Burns would be down there taking Senator Sherry's place.
—What about Barney?

—Yes, what about Senator Cooney? I do not think anyone on this side of the chamber would have said one word if it had been Senator Cooney, because then we would all have thought, yes, it was done on merit. But when we see some of the Parliamentary Secretaries that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has had to pay back, we on this side of the chamber say, `There are other reasons'.

PARA.TAB: What the people have to understand is that in this chamber, where the Hare-Clarke system of voting is undertaken, which is the true reflection of what the Australian public wants, the number of Government senators is now down to 30. Thirty members of the Labor Party got Senate seats. On this side of the chamber we got 36 seats. That is the true reflection of the voting of the people when it is not done on just those few dicey seats.

What has been occurring in this debate is a continuation of the downgrading of the Senate. We are all aware of the Prime Minister's reference to this chamber as unrepresentative swill. We on this side of the chamber take strong exception to it, even though those on the other side of the chamber do not care.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was talking about primary industry at the time.

PARA.TAB: Senator WALTERS—Indeed, as Senator Coates would readily acknowledge, the aim is to abolish the Senate. It is the unmitigated truth that the Labor Party wants to abolish the Senate. Senator Gareth Evans has been quoted as saying that he would come into the Senate and white-ant it from within. Senator Evans has said at Labor meetings, `Yes, we will have to take that off our party agenda, but there is no need for us not to work at it underneath'. Obviously his main purpose in coming into the Senate was to white-ant it from within.

At the moment the Government is wanting to take more and more power itself. As Senator Kemp has said, we now have additional Ministers and 10 Parliamentary Secretaries who will be pseudo-Ministers. Estimates in this place has been downgraded to such an extent that we have a Parliamentary Secretary, with no knowledge at all, taking the place of a Minister who is meant to be representing the Minister in the other place.

That is not the way the Senate should proceed and I would object very strongly to any suggestion that Parliamentary Secretaries should take the place of Ministers in the Estimates or in any other respect, for example at Question Time in here. We must have Her Majesty's Government Ministers in charge of those responsibilities, not Parliamentary Secretaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment:

PARA.TAB: That debate on this matter be adjourned until the first day of sitting of the Budget session.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not an amendment and you cannot move the adjournment because you have spoken on the motion.
—I would be happy to do it.
—Mr Deputy President, I think you will want to adjourn this debate now anyway for a first speech.
—I understand that the original intention was to adjourn at about this time, but that the intention now is to conclude the debate.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—No.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I am saying is that that was the intention of those on my right.
—I move:

PARA.TAB: That debate on this matter be adjourned until the first day of sitting of the Budget session.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should move the adjournment first and if that motion is carried, we then proceed to determine to which day it is adjourned.
—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the debate be now adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to explain why I think debate on the matter should be adjourned.
—Is leave granted?
—No.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) wishes to be churlish, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill making a statement relating to the motion to adjourn the debate. Question put.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Teague's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Faulkner.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was on my feet. I was called by the Deputy President.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I wish to speak on this matter.
—I had been called by the Deputy President.

—Honourable senators will realise that I was not in the chair prior to the divisions being called. I believed Senator Faulkner had the call. However, it is usual, if other people wish to speak, that they be allowed to do so. Perhaps it would be better to move the adjournment of this debate and move to the first speech.
