QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Environmental Protection Authority in Western Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to the recent sacking of the Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the EPA in Western Australia, Mr Barry Carbon, by the State Environment Minister, Mr Minson, and the sacking of three of the four independent members of the EPA in Western Australia. Firstly, will the Minister give full faith and credit, under the inter-governmental agreement on the environment, to the results of environmental assessment procedures carried out by the considerably weakened EPA? Secondly, what steps will the Minister take to ensure that the high quality of independent environmental assessment carried out formerly by the EPA in Western Australia is maintained? Finally, what steps will the Minister take to ensure that the national air and water quality standards agreed to by the proposed National Environment Protection Authority will be implemented through complementary legislation in Western Australia and rigorously enforced by the State EPA?

—I thank Senator Coulter for giving the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly, notice of this question earlier today. I have been provided with the following answer: the removal of Mr Carbon is clearly a matter for the Western Australian Government. The Commonwealth does not become involved in proposals in Western Australia unless a Commonwealth decision is required.

PARA.TAB: Commonwealth environmental assessment of projects in Western Australia is generally limited to those projects requiring export approval or approval under the Commonwealth's foreign investment policy. In circumstances where environmental assessments under the Commonwealth's Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act applies to Western Australian proposals, I can assure the Senate that a high standard of environmental protection will be maintained and the Commonwealth will not endorse any environmental assessment processes which fall short of these standards.

The intergovernmental agreement on the environment is now in place, having been agreed in May 1992. The Western Australian Government is a signatory. Officials of all States, including Western Australia, are presently meeting in the working group on environment policy to ensure that appropriate legislation will be drafted to implement the National Environment Protection Authority as provided in schedule four of the inter-governmental agreement on the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that his ever helpful colleague Senator Richardson unburdened himself today on the John Laws program with the following comments. He said that `pay TV in its history will not go down as one of the great triumphs of the Labor Government', that the `horse hadn't bolted—it's still in the paddock', and further that the tendering process should require an assessment of capacity to perform and ability to pay. Does the Minister welcome his colleague's comments? Does he agree with Senator Richardson's view that the tender process should have included requirements to put in place some hurdles prior to the price bidding to weed out fly-by-night speculators?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just asked Senator Cooney whether he would ask me this question as a dorothy dixer. Thanks very much.
—And he said no.

—No, he was writing it down when Senator Bishop got up to speak. With the greatest respect to my colleague—and indeed I have the greatest respect for my colleague—he was suffering under the same misapprehension as Senator Alston, the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, half the press gallery and, with the greatest of respect, the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: It is a very important question as to why these conditions had not been placed prior to the selection process. I will tell honourable senators why: it happened to be the department's preferred position and it sought to do it. As usual, the department sought advice from the Attorney-General, which I will table now instead of this afternoon. I do not have time to read it all, but I will read the relevant parts to answer Senator Bishop's question. Two alternatives were put in, one of which—the preferred one—was option A. Option A proposed five `hurdles'. The advice states:

ANSWER.PARA: Proposal A—
and this is the Attorney-General's response—
which is the preferred option . . .
It proposes five hurdles. They all relate to the matter Senator Bishop and everyone else has raised and sets them out. Proposal B was an alternative. The advice states:
Your questions and my short answers are:
(1) Q. Would a selection process based on the proposal—
that is, to put all these hurdles in—
be a priced-based allocation system within proposed s.93(1)?

PARA.TAB: A. In my view, no.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Q. If the selection process is a price-based allocation system, is there sufficient doubt on the matter to mean that there is a significant risk that the allocation process would be delayed by an applicant taking legal action upon being excluded from consideration for a non-price reason?

PARA.TAB: A. Yes.

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Q. If the selection process is not a price-based allocation system, is there a way of building the hurdles into the selection process in such a way that the system remains price-based?

PARA.TAB: A. I do not consider that the hurdles can be incorporated into a pre-qualification stage whereby some potential bidders are eliminated before their bids are assessed on a price basis.

ANSWER.PARA: It goes on to support the alternative proposal, which was to put these conditions on—as we have done—after the first selection was made on price.

PARA.TAB: Thank God I am not a lawyer and I do not presume to be, but that advice just makes sense to me. Senator Bishop is a lawyer and so is Senator Alston. I am told that the Sydney silk who cross-examined me in the Federal Court is one of the best. I was certainly told he was one of the highest priced and, if price based tendering processes mean anything, that must mean he is one of the best. He cast some aspersions on the deficiencies of Parliament. Maybe it is because we have so many lawyers in our ranks that we are so deficient. I think Senator Bishop, as a lawyer, should have known this, and so should Senator Alston. In the weekend press, Senator Alston—despite his previous position, expounded at length in the pay TV committee, that this should be a pure price based process—said that all these conditions should be put on. But the Attorney-General's Department said, `No, they can't be put on', and I think that advice is right.

Why was this a matter of concern to the department? I will tell the Senate why, and Senator Alston knows this: this industry litigates like no other, not just in Australia but around the world. The broadcasting industry and the allocation of licences is buried in litigation. In conclusion, I will give one example. The last merit based process—and with the greatest respect, this is one of the big deficiencies of merit based processes of which I am personally aware—was the allocation of the third commercial free to air television licence in Perth. That was a merit based system, a beauty contest. Of necessity, it took over two years to conduct because under natural justice we have to give every applicant the same opportunity to be tested. That process cost the public a fortune.

Senator Alston may be able to correct me on this because he would be as familiar with this case as I am. To the best of my recollection it provoked at least 15 legal actions and it ended up with a tender being allocated. Who picked up the value of it? The Government? No, the tenderer. The tenderer got the licence after two years, 15 legal actions and a fortune of public money spent on assessing these things. Senator Alston knows conditions cannot be applied to just one company; they have to be applied to all applicants in advance before we know what their prices are. I do not know how many multimillions Kerry Stokes got for that, but he sold the licence and, of course, the benefit was picked up. That is the problem with merit based processes because they often do not set the correct market price.

The short answer to Senator Bishop's question is because the Attorney-General's Department advised my department, whose preferred option it was to do just that, that it was not legally possible to do so, and I table the advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer again to the interview given by Senator Richardson in the course of the day. Mr Laws said, `I am hearing and have read on a couple of occasions that the model was outlaid by you when you were the Minister. Is that, the model that is being used, correct or incorrect?'. Answer: `No, vastly incorrect. The model that I laid down has been changed quite substantially'. Is Senator Collins, therefore, saying that Senator Richardson was an incompetent Minister?

—Senator Richardson's statements are correct. Senator Bishop should know because she was in here with her colleagues changing it. How could we forget when that original government model was excised from the Bill by the Senate and sent off, as I said at the time, to the black hole of a Senate committee from which I expected it never to emerge.
—No, I chaired it.

—Oh, Senator Schacht chaired it; I am sorry. It is a wonder we are not still in there now. What I said at that time, and in hindsight I think it would be the case, is that if those changes had not been made I do not think any of this would have happened, but what is the point of reflecting on this.

PARA.TAB: The principal issue on which it was referred to that Senate committee, which I opposed at the time but in hindsight I actually support, was to provide a unique feature of Australian television, which I hope is eventually provided, to make it distinct from all other pay TV services in the world, and that is the involvement of our national broadcaster in providing two channels of predominantly Australian content and, to use that pejorative term, quality television. That was the issue that sent it off to that committee. Despite all the conspiracy theories, all of which were tested during three hours of cross-examination in the Federal Court, the principal reason why I took the decision I did on MDS in January was to preserve the national role of the ABC in a pay television service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Schacht, the Minister for Science and Small Business. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to press reports stating that a consortium is proposing to establish a space port in Papua New Guinea? Can the Minister advise the Senate what impact that is likely to have on the Australian Cape York space program? Finally, how will this proposal in PNG affect our space program?

—The press statement by the Prime Minister of PNG announced an agreement for a Queensland company, Space Transportation Systems (STS), to conduct a feasibility study over a period of a few months relating to the possibility of establishing a space port somewhere in PNG, obviously close to the equator. This proposal is one of a series of proposals from companies wishing to conduct a space launch facility in a near-equatorial location. They seek to capitalise on the cost advantages which those locations provide for the launch of geostationary communication satellites.

PARA.TAB: While there has been significant interest in such proposals, no-one has yet managed to obtain the necessary financial backing. The PNG study is unlikely to have any immediate major effect on the proposals for establishing the Cape York space port. We are advised that the efforts of an Australian company to obtain funding for the Cape York space port are continuing.

The firm of STS was proposed to be involved in a space port at Cape York, but it was withdrawn by the Queensland Government two or three years ago because I do not think it could show any ability to raise the money. I did note with some interest today that Mr Borbidge, the Leader of the National Party in Queensland, has attacked the Federal and Queensland governments for not doing enough for the space port at Cape York. Apparently he was the Minister for Space in the Queensland Government when Mr Ahern was the Premier. Mr Ahern is now the leader of the STS project to try to build a space port in PNG. In regard to the impact on Cape York, we have made it quite clear that if a commercial venture wants to invest the money, we will look at it. So far that money has not come forward from any consortium.

As far as our own program is concerned, in the past six or seven months the Australian Government has appointed a new Space Council to take advantage of Australia's skills, where available, for a space program. Australia does possess a number of competitive and comparative advantages in space activities which we can capitalise upon, such as industrial expertise in aerospace and telecommunications, a very strong applications-oriented remote sensoring community, and a geographic advantage for launch services for low-orbiting satellites.

The Space Council is now preparing a five-year program to maximise our ability to put together a space program. I hope that in the next few months that will be made a public document. I also hope that at some time in the latter part of this year, as previously promised, we will introduce legislation to make the Space Council a statutory authority, as previously announced. All in all, I believe that we have a considerable opportunity to maximise within our resources a space program.

I would like to draw to the attention of all honourable senators the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure of April 1992 entitled Developing Satellite Launching Facilities in Australia and the Role of Government. It was a bipartisan report which suggested that there were opportunities for Australia to be involved in a limited space program within our resources. I expect to be given bipartisan support when the Space Council comes down with its five-year program.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Some 40 per cent of south-west Queensland's drought stricken properties have been unable to access RAS interest subsidies in the past because they cannot meet the Government's viability guidelines. How many of these properties will now be able to access interest rate subsidies under the `exceptional circumstances' provisions of the recently announced Crean package? Can the Minister give an undertaking to the Parliament that the Crean package will prevent most of the 40 per cent of producers from leaving their land and their industry?

—On behalf of Minister Simon Crean, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, I will refer to some notes I have on this matter which go to an answer. On 28 April, Minister Crean announced that the Government allocated an additional $11 million to provide support under the exceptional circumstances provisions of the rural adjustment scheme—RAS, as it was referred to in Senator Boswell's question—to drought affected farmers in Queensland and New South Wales for the period 1 July to 31 December 1992.

PARA.TAB: This drought assistance has been integrated with the exceptional circumstances support to wool producers which means that $5 million of the $44.6 million of the wool support has been allocated to help drought affected wool producers. The remaining $6 million is to support the other drought affected producers.

Including this latest allocation, the Commonwealth has now provided special drought assistance of $27.5 million since September 1992. Drought affected producers may be eligible for interest subsidies of up to 100 per cent on existing and new loans for carry-on, debt restructuring and productivity improvement purposes. For 100 per cent subsidies to be provided, Queensland and New South Wales will be required to match subsidies above 50 per cent on a dollar for dollar basis, which means they will need to contribute $2.6 million. The cap of $30,000 per applicant which applied to the special drought assistance from 1992-93 has been increased—that is, the cap has gone up—to $50,000 for 1993-94 assistance. To be eligible for an interest rate subsidy under the exceptional circumstances provisions, Queensland producers should apply to the Queensland Industry Development Corporation, which administers the RAS scheme in Queensland on behalf of the Commonwealth. Each application is assessed on a case by case basis, taking into account a full assessment of the producer's current and projected financial situation. I think that covers some of Senator Boswell's questions.

In relation to Senator Boswell's other questions on the viability guidelines, these are developed in consultation with States to ensure that assistance is provided to those people most in need but who also have prospects for long term profitability. For those who are found to be unviable in the long term, additional assistance is available under the farm household support scheme which provides generous support for those who have intentions of moving out of farming. I will respond to the other elements of Senator Boswell's question later on. I will take those elements on notice and respond as soon as I can.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environmental Protection Authority in Western Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter on 5 May 1993 relating to the Environmental Protection Authority in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter asked the Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht, what he was doing regarding the removal of Barry Carbon from the position of head of the EPA in Western Australia. In the short time I have I wish to put the record straight. The Government of Western Australia is not in any way ridding the EPA of Barry Carbon. His contract expires on 30 June this year and that is when he will be able to apply for a job, if he so wishes, in a new sphere. The WA Government is splitting his job into two. He holds the job of CEO and chairman of the authority. On 1 July the Government of WA is splitting that job into two, which is a very common practice in the authority.

PARA.TAB: What the WA Government did cancel, after receiving a legal opinion, was a contract entered into by the previous Minister seven days before an election and six months prior to the date that Barry Carbon's contract was to expire. So it is simply a situation of the new Government of WA splitting the job into two. It is not unloading Barry Carbon. He is free to apply for any of the two jobs if he so wishes. This matter should be left to the State of WA.

I do not mind saying this. I have known Barry Carbon for a mighty long time, going back 25 years when he was a top footballer for Western Australia. I suggest that Senator Coulter check his facts before he makes any more accusations about the Western Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Western Australian Minister, Mr Minson, made it quite clear during the Western Australian election campaign that he would not split the jobs. In relation to what Senator Panizza has just said about these jobs frequently being split, there are at least seven other departments in Western Australia in which the positions of head of a board and chief executive officer are occupied by the same person.

PARA.TAB: In the lead-up to the election, the very conservative red-necked Western Australian government-in-waiting was using the advice of Dr Tim Meagher, a man well known for very considerable environmental damage in Western Australia. The new Western Australian Government now wants to get rid of Barry Carbon, somebody in whom the conservation movement in Western Australia was not particularly confident when first appointed, but over the years he has proved to be a man of considerable integrity and independence. While one would not agree with every decision which the EPA has made—the Democrats are on record as opposing the decision of the EPA to support the petrochemical plant, for example—nonetheless, in the main Barry Carbon has shown considerable independence and is an excellent person to fulfil that role.

There is a clear political move going on in Western Australia to interfere with the independence of the EPA and to appoint a person who is acceptable to the Western Australian Government but who is a known environmental destroyer. Clearly, the crux of the question was—I am not entirely satisfied with the reply of the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) on behalf of the Minister in the other place—that, under the intergovernmental agreement, we may well get to a situation where the Western Australian EPA is no longer independent and where the decisions which the EPA gives on things such as EISs and EIAs are very strongly coloured.

Therefore, the question still stands: will the Federal Government simply sit on its hands and allow very considerable environmental destruction to go on in Western Australia, instead of, as I believe it should do if that situation develops, stepping in and making sure that that very considerable portion of the Australian environment is protected? That is the proper function of a comprehensive Federal Government. The question specifically mentioned things such as air quality and water quality standards.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I wish to say, as I said in my answer to Senator Coulter, that the Federal Government will not deviate from its commitment to proper environmental standards. Obviously, as individual issues arise they will be judged on their merits but we will not deviate from our standard as a national government where we have the appropriate power.

PARA.TAB: I also want to point out to Senator Coulter that, as I understand it, at the last State election in Western Australia the Democrats actually directed their preferences to the Liberal Party. That may have assisted the Liberal Party in winning the election. Without making a great point of it, I hope next time a State election occurs in Western Australia or elsewhere, he considers very carefully giving his preferences holus bolus to the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address this issue. Firstly, my understanding is that at the last election the Australian Democrats ran on an open ticket. I do not think the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) was correct in what he said. As usual, Senator Coulter came in and used emotional terms such as `environmental destroyer', when he did not know what he was talking about. He claimed that things were done with regard to the position of Mr Barry Carbon. Incidentally, I have quite a high regard for Mr Barry Carbon.

PARA.TAB: It was made quite clear prior to the last election that, as far as the running of the EPA in Western Australia was concerned, the position of chief executive officer and chairman would be split. There is no doubt about that. As I understand it, that proposal was also considered by the previous Labor Government. This situation is the result of the enormous amount of conflict in Western Australia between the EPA, conservation and land management, industry and a number of other organisations, including conservation groups in Western Australia. That is well and truly on the public record. So when Senator Coulter comes in here and makes these claims about Western Australia, I have to say that he is way off the beam.

I want to make another point about this matter. Senator Coulter referred to environmental destruction. Firstly, the record of the EPA in some areas of Western Australia is very good. In other areas it is not so good. CALM is in the same category. However, it became patently obvious to anybody who was sitting back looking at what has been happening, particularly in the last 12 or 18 months, that it was necessary to reassess both the position that the EPA was adopting and EPA's administration.

Mr Barry Carbon was not precluded from applying for either of the jobs, be it chairman or chief executive officer. Similar steps could be taken in respect of a number of other organisations. I will mention one—the Rural Adjustment Authority, which was referred to in an answer to a question from Senator Boswell.

Senator Coulter rose in this chamber and made claims about what is happening. There was a clear policy position prior to the election as far as the incumbent government of Western Australia was concerned. We should now allow the restructured Environment Protection Authority in Western Australia to get on with the job of achieving a balance between environmental requirements and sustainable development in Western Australia in order to help overcome some of the serious problems that exist as a result of unemployment, not only in Western Australia but in Australia as a whole.

Western Australia is capable of making a significant contribution to achieving a proper balance between development and the environment, and that is borne out by recent unemployment figures. I believe that the proposed changes to the structure of the EPA will enhance that process. It certainly will not inhibit it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pick up Senator Crane's concluding words about achieving a proper balance between employment and the protection of the environment. On the same day as the announcement of the sacking of Mr Carbon in Western Australia, the State Government announced that it was going to explore for oil on the Ningaloo Reef—an area that is very precious to the citizens of Western Australia, Australia and the world. While it is not an immediate rival in size to the Great Barrier Reef, which runs around the eastern seaboard of Australia, it is certainly something that we are very keen to protect.

PARA.TAB: It is fortunate that Senator Crane drew attention to the link between the protection of the environment and employment. During that dreadful week, the Western Australian State Government not only cut Barry Carbon's throat but also slashed over 1,000 jobs at the Midland railroad workshops, which is another clear breach of an election promise made by the Court Government.

It hid for five weeks while the Federal election was held, but it has come out of the woodwork since then. In today's West Australian we see the announcement of hundreds of Western Australian jobs being lost at an abattoir. I doubt whether that is something that my rural colleagues on the Opposition benches would agree with.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a senator for Western Australia, as well as for the Greens (WA), I want to support the validity and importance of Senator Coulter's question. There is no question that the State Government of Western Australia has put the leadership of the EPA under threat. Not only that, it has virtually decimated the membership of the EPA. The decisions made over the last two years have been placed under question. It is perfectly appropriate to ask what role the Federal Government is going to take to protect Western Australia's precious environmental resources from the decimation that is occurring now.

PARA.TAB: The State Government has made public commitments over the last two months to re-open the national parks for mining and to present legislation to pre-empt the Mabo legislation giving Aboriginal people their rights to justice for the first time. As Senator McKiernan mentioned, the State Government has opened the Ningaloo Reef, which is the second most precious reef in Australia to the Great Barrier Reef, to oil exploration.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one has ever heard of it.

—That shows Senator MacGibbon's ignorance. The Ningaloo Reef is as valuable as the Great Barrier Reef and is worthy of that protection. It should not be opened for oil exploration, as has been announced by the Minister for Mines, Mr Cash. The State Government has also supported a nuclear reactor for Western Australia and has promoted the idea of re-opening the issue of uranium mining in the Rudall River area, which is very important for Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: People often ask me why the Greens are doing so well in Western Australia when there is such a redneck, conservative attitude over there in regard to environmental and social justice issues. I say to them, `That is why'. The State Government is not providing the protection for the environment and the processes of social justice that are deserved by the community of Western Australia. It is most pertinent to ask what the Federal Government is going to do in that regard. I commend Senator Coulter for raising that question in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter raised by Senator Coulter was a concern about the move to work against the independence of this body and the steps which were taken—after being flagged before the election—to remove that independence.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane questioned whether those moves to remove the independence had actually been noticed before the election. Although I would like to accept Senator Crane's assertions about the election and where preferences went, the position that was put by the Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht, was in fact the case. If Senator Crane could not get that right, it is very important that we question his credibility as to what he got right in the rest of his contribution. I think he should be very careful in saying others should get their facts right before they come in here when he cannot get a few basic facts about the election right.

The fact is that Mr Minson is recorded as saying what direction he would take. The direction has been to compromise the independence of this body. The only thing that Australians can rely upon to protect their environmental concerns in these areas is an independent review body. That independence has been compromised by these actions.

Mr Barry Carbon, as Senator Coulter said, may well have been a CSIRO scientist with an Alcoa background and there may have been some suspicion about his credibility and independence by those who are concerned about the future of the environment, but the track record is there. His independence was proven and his decisions were admired for that reason. To compromise that independence through a blatantly political move is something which Senator Coulter rightly drew attention to and asked questions about. The answers are not satisfactory and I know Senator Coulter will continue to pursue this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to rebut two observations which have been made. Senator Chamarette criticised the Liberal Party and said how well the Greens were doing in Western Australia. She is about to be joined by a colleague who was elected on our preferences. If she does not like that, I can arrange for the preferences to go to the Labor Party instead.

PARA.TAB: I am obliged to make one observation with respect to Senator McKiernan's observations. I am staggered that he would have the gall and the audacity to criticise the Liberal Government, which has been in office for two months, after the record of the Labor Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —Three.

—For three months. The Labor Party's record is: one ex-Premier presently in court, one ex-Deputy Premier in court, another ex-Premier found by a royal commission to have acted grossly improperly, a number of Ministers who were sacked or who resigned as a result of their conduct, a billion dollars of taxpayers' funds lost over rorting and scandalous association with dubious business people in Western Australia, record unemployment, record bankruptcies, record levels of corruption, record waiting queues for hospitals, and a record level of young people who cannot get into tertiary education. The Labor Government was dumped ignominiously out of office and Senator McKiernan has the audacity to stand here and criticise a government which is putting those things right.

PARA.TAB: The contribution to the environment of Senator McKiernan's colleague Judith Watson was to prevent an aircraft from flying over Marandoo to do aeromagnetic work because she believed that it would create aberrations over an alleged Aboriginal sacred site. Not only did she ban superficial exploration; she banned aircraft flying over the sacred site because of the destruction the aberrations would cause. And Senator McKiernan wonders why development came to a grinding halt in Western Australia and why there is record unemployment.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Jones this day, relating to a proposed space agency in Queensland.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The appalling failure of the Minister for Transport and Communications to accept his ministerial responsibilities in relation to the pay television satellite licence fiasco.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —In many ways it is disappointing that we come back to the first formal day of Parliament to find that not only is the Government on the ropes but that all its bad habits have gone from bad to worse. It seems to me that what we have already had in Question Time today from Senator Collins—I will come to some of Senator Evans's legal opinions later—is a redefinition of the principle of ministerial responsibility. Senator Collins would have us believe that there is a presumption of ministerial idiocy. In other words, we ought to treat a Minister as knowing nothing about anything. He ought to be entitled to be informed about any change in policy, administration or anything that might be of interest to him because we can presume that he is a complete idiot.

PARA.TAB: We are not dealing with a tyro; we are not dealing with someone who has just come into the job and done quite well in a short period of time. It is quite the opposite. Here is a bloke who has been on board for about three years, with all the perks of office and all the rewards that go with being a Minister, but a man who has an abject unwillingness to accept any of the responsibilities of high office. That is not just a personal tragedy; it is also a very serious matter of concern for the Parliament and the administration of government.

We need to demolish at the outset the preposterous nonsense that Senator Collins keeps trotting out that if we do not have a merit based system, we must have a price based allocation system in which no Minister can have any part to play. In other words, `Don't dare ask me to intervene in any shape or form, because if I did that I would be accused of favouring my mates, and that is the last thing I want to do'. One does not have to be a complete idiot to understand that the terms and conditions of the administrative arrangements can be defined without in any shape or form favouring any of the participants. If the Jack Waterford principle has any relevance, it is simply that Ministers should not intervene in tenders and do so at their peril if they want to advantage one or more of the parties. That is completely different from the concept of ministerial responsibility for what goes on in Senator Collins's department.

Let us start where we should start in all these matters, and that is at the beginning. The beginning is section 93 of the Broadcasting Services Act. It says that the Minister is to determine in writing a price based allocation system. It does not say that it is up to the junior bureaucrat to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That means I do it myself, does it? What nonsense!

—That is precisely what it does not mean. Senator Collins wants to see these things in black and white. He used to be a jockey; I suppose there were weighty reasons why he gave that game away. I assure him that he is a real lightweight when it comes to media law. He clearly does not understand the difference between being involved in every little detail and accepting responsibility for what others do in his department.

PARA.TAB: What that section states is a very hallowed principle. `The Minister is to determine' means that the Minister is fixed with ultimate responsibility. It does not go on and spell out, chapter and verse, how to do these things; it simply leaves it to the discretion of the Minister, taking advice from the department and any outside experts that he chooses to rely on. But if he adopts the approach of closing his eyes and saying, `Today is the 19th of January and I've got much better things to do in the Northern Territory. I'm the State President of the ALP; I've got a lot of mobile polling booths to run around. All I'll do is sign a document put in front of me. I'll do it on a wing and a prayer, hoping that if there is anything of any significance the department will bring it to my attention'. That is not the basis on which the Minister is paid a very good salary. He is paid to exercise some individual judgment.

We do not put people into ministerial offices—normally, anyway; and we certainly would not on our side—unless we think they have some degree of competence. It follows from that that we expect them to exercise judgment and discretion. We expect them to read what is put in front of them, not to adopt the Jim Cairns defence and say, `I know it involved $4,000 million, but really I was in a bit of a hurry'.

What about all the stuff that was given us today? Senator Collins said, `I get 200 ministerial submissions a week. I'm a very busy boy. I should therefore be entitled to be told of anything of any significance so I can just claim all the credit. I'll sign everything in sight. Anything you put on my table, you can get my signature on it, as long as you haven't warned me not to. If it looks good, of course I'll be all over the front page claiming the credit'.

We have quite the opposite situation here. Not only do we have a bloke who says, `I don't bother reading the documents', but apparently he does not even read the newspapers. I could understand why he is not reading the Financial Review when it has headlines like `Collins' job on line over pay television fiasco', but most people would say that in this job reading the newspapers is not an optional extra. One normally reads them to see what is going on. If the Minister chooses not to want to know what is going on, it is perfectly consistent with the approach he took in signing the determination—and sign it he did because he was required by law to sign it. In signing that document, he was spelling out the parameters of the administrative arrangements to be put in place.

As Senator Bishop pointed out to me a moment ago, Minister Collins signed under section 93. Section 92 of the Act actually applied to MDS licences and it has no more or less ambit than section 93—it says `may' instead of `must'. Section 92A(1) states, `The Minister may determine . . . a price-based allocation system'. That means that it is up to the Minister to work out how to do it, and that is what he did. He took advice—if one could call it advice—and he asked his department to provide him with a form of determination, to which he put his name. One should not have a glass of beer in one hand and a blindfold in the other and say, `Where do I sign?'. One should actually read the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't actually drink, Senator Alston.

—Then Senator Collins obviously had the blindfold in both hands. His defence is, `I looked at this, but I did not appreciate the significance of it'. Again, that is an appallingly weak defence because the Minister's obligation is to read the document thoroughly, take advice if he does not understand it, but, most of all, not to do these things in a vacuum.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins is not the new boy; he has been around for a while. He ought to remember the FM radio licence fiasco when Bond Media bid $23 million, fell over, forfeited about $100 and the next in line had to pay only $10 million to get the licence. That was an absolute farce. In the 1980s we were a laughing-stock because of that sort of behaviour. We chose, quite rightly, not to go for beauty contests, for all the reasons Senator Collins mentioned. We went for price-based allocation systems, but we did it on particular terms. As the Minister well knows, and as he should have known because he was the presiding Minister, we did it in relation to the third mobile telephone licence and also we did it in MDS. If there is one thing Senator Collins should have learnt in his term as Minister for Communications, it is that a price-based allocation system on previous occasions has involved the payment of a substantial up-front deposit. So there can be no argument that it is within the power of the Minister, the department, or both, to prescribe just that.

Do not let us have any nonsense that somehow, because this is a price-based system, the Minister is not entitled to attach any terms and conditions. There are eight pages here, all spelling out the way in which it is to be done. One of the obvious terms and conditions was precisely that it not favour any of the parties. Indeed, why does the Minister at this stage, half way through the game, want to change the rules and to introduce an amendment which would now require the successive bidders, if the first lot fall over, to come up with 5 per cent? He is doing that because he concedes that it is perfectly proper to do it. In other words, it should have been done in the first instance. Why was it not done in the first instance? It was not done because someone else is to blame.

For the past four or five days Senator Collins has vilified, castigated and kicked to death his own department, and now he says, `I will ask them to conduct an inquiry into themselves'. In other words, he is asking them to sign their own death warrant. That again, I would have thought, is so manifestly unfair that it is unconscionable. Again, the Minister is trying to deflect attention from his statutory obligations. He is the one required to spell out the ambit and the parameters. He is the one who manifestly has failed to do so.
All I can say is that there could not be a clearer case of failure to exercise ministerial responsibility. It is worth just looking briefly at a couple of examples of how this has been defined.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has read the cover, but not the contents.
—That is right, but we cannot even say he is just a pretty face.
—Do you want to talk about Tony Staley?

—I will come to him in a moment. If Senator Collins had read the Financial Review, he would have seen one of the greatest backhanded compliments one could have in this game. It is the Bill Hayden line. Tom Burton goes through it and explains why poor old Senator Collins has to go. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Collins signed a determination outlining rules for the tender. It may well be his death warrant as a minister.

PARA.TAB: Cabinet had four chances over a period of two years to reject the new system.

SPEECH.PARA: He continues:

PARA.TAB: Now wriggling on the hook, he has told Opposition Senators he will have a high-level departmental inquiry into how the omission occurred.

That would be far too easy. It is standard political play for a Minister under siege to blame the bureaucrats but, if the concept of ministerial responsibility is to have any meaning, then the evidence leaves no other conclusion than that Collins has to go.

SPEECH.PARA: Then, of course, he makes the point that Senator Collins has prior convictions. He says:
Collins cannot claim he is a first-time offender.

PARA.TAB: He clearly never understood the impact of microwave technology.

SPEECH.PARA: We know of that absolute fiasco where he got himself in court, having to commit pious perjury and pretend that somehow it was all his decision, when we know who threatened to rip whose arms off and to what extent the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) called the shots on that little issue.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —But, as Senator Hill quite rightly says, that is a debate for another day. Going to Senator Collins's second prior conviction—and Tom Burton says in passing, of course, that that was a massive overreaction—he says:

PARA.TAB: Collins was also the minister who presided over the debacle surrounding the tender for the Civil Aviation Authority's new air traffic control system. He not only presided over it, but strongly endorsed a process—

SPEECH.PARA: which was subsequently described as unsound and unfair.Tom Burton comes to the Bill Hayden line, which I always remember because I remember this cartoon of Bill Hayden. They are all outside the Caucus and this bloke comes up to Bill and he says, `Bill, you're in big trouble. They all reckon you're a good bloke'. And that is what Tom Burton says. He says:
Collins is the sort of politician everyone likes.
I would not go that far.
An intelligent and genuinely nice bloke—

Again, I suppose he is trying to let down Senator Collins gently. But we can understand the thrust. He is basically saying, `A good bloke out of his depth shouldn't be in the big league and really should get back to running that Opposition in the Northern Territory, where they want him to go quick smart'. He has not taken the offer as yet, as I understand it.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, when we look at what the concept of ministerial responsibility really means, I can do no better than to go back to the dark days of 1982 when Senator Durack was under siege in relation to the activities of a junior clerk. We had the likes of Senator Evans trotting out the doctrine of ministerial responsibility, quoting Malcolm Fraser. He said about Ministers:

SPEECH.PARA: They ought to be aware of all the major matters and therefore can be clearly and directly responsible for them. But if a major blunder occurred in a department—
and I would have thought that is precisely what Senator Collins has been saying in recent days—
of real importance to Australia—

and again we are talking, as I recall, in Senator Collins's terms, about 4,000 jobs and hundreds of millions of dollars; so it is of real importance if he wants to try to cure that Budget deficit, hoping to get his $389 million before the Budget—
. . . if the Minister were unaware of it, that minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign.

That principle is not just one that Jack Waterford thinks is a good idea; all the writers on the subject say the same thing. We could not do better than go to a luminary of the stature of a chap called Robert James Lee Hawke. In deploring the reduction of the concept of ministerial accountability, he said that resignation was required of a Minister where a significant act or omission was theirs, or was taken at their personal discretion, or was a matter about which they obviously should have known and done something.

PARA.TAB: What lawyers talk about is actual or constructive knowledge. In other words, if Senator Collins did not know, he ought to have known.

That is precisely what Senator Collins ought to have known. He presided over MDS, he presided over the third mobile licence, he knew that they both attracted a substantial up-front deposit, and yet he signed the very document that did not allow that to happen. He simply required the payment of a mickey mouse $500. Indeed, as someone said to me yesterday, `You wouldn't believe this, but they didn't even want a bank cheque. I asked them if they would take a personal cheque and they said yes, that would be all right.' So one could even bounce one's own cheque. One would not even be up for $500, if one did not want to be.

What we have is probably the clearest possible case. Again, just looking at what some of the journalists have been writing, the question now gripping Canberra is who should be held responsible for the process. If Senator Collins had his way, it would be everyone but himself. He started off by saying it was the Opposition, then it was the Senate, and now it is the department. He is running out of scapegoats. I would have thought that, apart from being utterly irresponsible, it is a shameless performance.

If Senator Collins understands the very basic distinction, which he seems to show no interest in understanding today, between a merit-based and price-based system, I hope he will not have the temerity to stand up and say that a price-based allocation system would not have allowed him to attach any preconditions. The obvious precondition was to pay the 5 per cent. He could also have required the companies to be incorporated for at least three months, which would have taken one of these players out of the game immediately. He could have required that people did not have criminal convictions. He could have required that the people involved in those companies had at least filed an annual return.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know whether you could.
—One could, because the ABA has a statutory responsibility to look at the business record of the company.
—Correct. Have a look a the advice. But it was not lawful to pre-empt the role of the ABA.
—The great trouble Senator Collins has with that advice is that he was not aware of it at the time.
—I didn't want to be.

—You didn't want to be? So Senator Collins said, `For God's sake, don't tell me anything that might be relevant. Don't for a moment tell me anything that might involve any decision making on my part where I might have to exercise discretion. I don't want to know about it. Give me your final draft and tell me where I sign'.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, but if it goes wrong, we know who will be copping it. Senator Collins cannot simply say that there might have been interesting legal questions to be resolved. He had the discretion and was required to exercise judgment but did nothing. All he says is, `I saw this $500 but it didn't ring a bell with me, so I signed'. That is the classic example of an abdication of responsibility. That is what the game is all about.

PARA.TAB: If ministerial responsibility means anything, it is being responsible for what one signs. In this context there were a whole range of discretions, far short of beauty contests, that could have attached to a price-based allocation system. It is not defined, as Senator Collins would know. All it really says is that price ought to be the ultimate determinant.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't say that.

—But it does not say price only, because if it did one could not even specify that one had to put the bid in an envelope. We have eight pages telling us how it ought to be done; one of those points is that one has to put $500 on the table. If one could put $500 on the table then one could put $5 million or even five per cent, as the Government's amendment clearly concedes could have happened.

PARA.TAB: The only reason the Minister is acting in this way is that he is now trying to cover his back. What he has done is to make it abundantly clear, in one fell swoop, that he does not think these two applicants will get to the line.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not correct.

—It is. The very fact that Senator Collins said in the first paragraph that that was not his intention pretty much shows that he has a guilty conscience on the issue. It can be interpreted in no other way.

PARA.TAB: What I said consistently was that there were very great concerns in the industry about whether this bid was a realistic one. As Senator Collins and I well know, it is a common belief that the major players bid only a small fraction of what is here. On the Business Sunday program Senator Collins piously said, `I cannot know and I will not know how many were there and what they bid'. But Beddall said the opposite. He said, `Of course, they were all very substantial bids'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Mr Beddall.

—Sorry, Mr Deputy President. Mr Beddall appears to know. I hope he knows a bit more about ministerial responsibility. I hope Senator Collins will go off and get a lesson on the subject, and in due course accept his responsibility and do the honourable thing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is probably more information about ministerial responsibility in terms of material available now than any other subject on earth. A very subjective view is taken. Senator Alston has invited me to give the Senate my view on the subject and I will. I have moved a few censure motions in my time, and I have called for enough resignations during my 10 years in opposition to find this a very familiar debate. The problem is that Senator Alston's speech does not address the political context on which this entire process was based. I have not forgotten it.
—That there was an election on?

—No, I am not talking about that. The press was wall to wall when I was in the Federal Court as a result of these matters—I might add, when I did not have to be—addressing these questions of impropriety, helping out mates and intervening to ensure that there would be a predetermined outcome and so on.
—That was after this.

—No, it was not. Senator Alston should have a look at what was said in the press prior to Christmas and in particular the statements made by him and by Hewson. Then he should have a look at the statements made after Christmas by Tim Fischer—
—Order!

—Mr Fischer talked about mysterious people coming to Canberra and fixing it up. All those statements were totally baseless. Today, in an interesting interview on AM, Senator Alston said that I was negligent. That was the charge laid by him. Why did he say I was negligent? Because I had not intervened to put on five per cent or $5 million as a precondition.

PARA.TAB: I have a very great regard for this Parliament, for any Parliament, and for ministerial responsibility. The Senate cannot possibly make a harder judgment on me than I continually make on myself in that regard. In my view it involves three elements: first, a Minister behaving with propriety and, second, a Minister behaving responsibly in every sense of that word. Those two issues cover matters such as deliberately misleading a House. In my view, when a Minister fails in those two elements it is a hanging offence.

We then come to the third element, that of competence, which also is important. That is where one gets into the highly subjective area of ministerial responsibility. The charge that has been laid against me today is based on competence. I have been accused by Senator Alston—he has laid it out today by going round and round on the same subject 50 times—that I was not exercising due diligence by sitting down like a corporate lawyer and second-guessing the department. Of course, I could not have done it unless I had had the intention of making some changes. I will put the question of propriety and responsibility on the charge because, while Senator Alston has only accused me of negligence, other people have accused me of plenty more, to the extent of formally doing so in the Federal Court. That charge is still sitting there awaiting a determination.

There were three avenues to that court case. The first two related to the narrow legal question of whether the determination that I issued in January was lawful. It will be an interesting test. I received advice from the department that it was lawful. Subsequently that advice was confirmed by the Attorney-General's Department, with the concurrence of the Commonwealth Solicitor-General, Mr Rose, that it was lawful. But, as Senator Alston knows better than I do, the Federal Court will finally determine that matter.

Senator Alston should have a look at the third avenue which is in the applicant's submissions. I might add that the matter was a very public process in that the courtroom was full of press, and the transcripts of proceedings are publicly available. This third avenue went to the most serious charge that can be laid against a Minister in relation to any matter, and that is abuse of public office—misfeasance. All the horrendous allegations—that the Prime Minister did this and he ordered me to do that—were baseless. Senator Alston knows that this was the political context in which this process was going ahead. Those allegations are all garbage.

Despite making all those allegations in writing to the Federal Court, I was not called to give evidence. I did not have to give evidence. Counsel acting for me said, `Look, if there is no requirement for you to appear in the court, it is a matter for you entirely. We're perfectly happy to go to the court, but on the written evidence there are no grounds for making these charges. It is a matter for your decision as to whether you go'. I have a very simple view of the Australian judicial system, and I still hope that I will die holding the view. My view is that if one knows that the charge is false and one goes to court and tells the truth, one will have nothing to fear from an Australian court.

Having spent 16 years in public office, I did not relish the prospect of going to court. I have never been to court and been cross-examined under oath. In court criminal sanctions apply to anybody who seeks to mislead. I went to the court and I was cross-examined for three hours on those first two tests of ministerial responsibility; that is, the propriety of how I behaved. It is all there in the transcript.

The reason I am making this point is that there is hardly anything left that can be turned up. We have been FOI' d to death. All the documents are in the Federal Court and, as a result of court orders, they are also in the hands of the press. I will make sure, and I have asked the secretary of the department to do so, that the two or three bits of paper that have happened since then will also be provided to Senator Alston or the Senate.

I believe that this is the appropriate debate in which to canvass this matter. As Senator Alston knows, he cannot be cute and just say, `I've only accused you of incompetency'. He knows perfectly well what this debate is about. Just have a look at what has been said in the press in the last 48 hours. I picked up a story the other day that said that we changed the process. The latest one of putting in amendments as a result of industry pressure to fix the figure at five per cent is absolute nonsense.

On the question of negligence, Senator Alston asks, `Why did I not just shove $5 million onto it; that would not have made any difference?'. That is not how it would have been judged in here or anywhere else. I immediately would have been asked, `Why, of your own volition, did you want to second-guess this department, which during your time as Minister has had an impeccable record'—and it has—`of letting major broadcasting tenders for radio, television and telecommunications?'. We have just banked the $70 million from the third mobile licence. Senator Alston is enough of a politician to know that that is true. I had absolutely no reason to believe in a real sense that the department would not carry out the mechanics of this process in the same competent way that it has carried out the mechanics of major tenders since I have been a Minister.

Was there any systemic failure? In other words, was there something that a Minister could properly be responsible for? Had a Minister been alerted to a consistent flow of mistakes through the department? No. What is the procedure, Senator Alston? The honourable senator knows that it is not a procedure that operates just in my office; it operates in any Minister's office, and I have checked it. As one Minister said to me, unless it is specifically flagged that the department is going to vary previous procedure in terms of process, of course a Minister does not assume that it is. The procedure is quite simple and I am very familiar with it.

The department has a responsibility, even with minor variations, to seek approval specifically, not just to provide a piece of paper saying, `Here is an outline of the process'. I might add that there is no reason for me to make any assumption that that was the total process. That is not good enough, and it is not. It has to be specifically flagged that it is going to be changed. Well, it was not. Was there any systemic failure? No, but there was a failure in this case and I have taken the appropriate action. So that is the situation.

What did I know about the process? The determination arrived in my Darwin office. Although it was two months before the election, I actually was not running around mobile polls, Senator Alston. Almost all of my ministerial staff were on leave because—and I think most other Ministers would probably have this arrangement—January is the only time of the year that they can get a break. I am glad that Senator Alston at least agrees with that. Last year was a pretty hard year—not that that is an element of this at all. I am simply describing exactly what happened. I knew what had previously happened. I knew that the department's communication selection team had been working on this. I knew that internal advice had been flowing backwards and forwards between the Attorney-General's Department, checking out the validity of the process.

I received the determination. I got a phone call from the department—I actually took the call myself because I had only one secretary in the Darwin office—asking, `Is the determination there?'. I said, `Yes.' I asked, `Has it been cleared by Attorney-General's?'. I was told, `Yes, it has been cleared by Attorney-General's; indeed, there is written advice to that effect'. I signed the determination.

Senator Alston asserts—and he knows this is unreal—that I should have sat down with that determination, like a corporate lawyer—which, of course, I am not; but I would not have done it anyway—and assumed that the process was flawed and that I should have second-guessed the department and said, `Hang on, is this condition in the industry bit at variance?'. Of course, that is absolute nonsense. I saw the $500, as Senator Alston knows perfectly well, because I briefed him on it. I assumed it was nothing else—and it is—but a lodgment fee. Can I just say this now: there was no deposit. That was the decision that was taken. There was no deposit asked for. And it is breathtaking. It was simply a paper shuffling charge. That is all that I assumed it was, and that is in fact what the secretary of the department has advised me it was.

Let me just say this—perhaps this is taking ministerial responsibility too far, but I do not think so: not only had I made an absolute decision, and I think in all the political circumstances reasonably, that I was not going to change a comma or a full stop in the process for this particular tender, but I told the senior private secretary in my office last year that I did not want any member of my office to interfere with the process that was going—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you sign it?

—That is correct, I did. I will tell the honourable senator why, and the Federal Court demonstrated this. I am perfectly well aware that even a phone call to the department generates a file note, all of which properly is recoverable. I can just imagine what would happen in the real world if there were communications between my officers saying, `Is this high enough, or is that high enough, or should you change this and that?' What would happen if I tried to say in here, `Oh well, they were not doing it on my authority at all'. Of course, I would have been believed by Senator Alston! What nonsense! The fact is that, rightly or wrongly—and I think rightly—I made a decision not to intervene in this process.
—You signed whatever they served up.
—Senator Alston should go back and have a look at the press. He should go back and have a look at the context—
—Look at the document.

—Not the document, Senator Alston. As I said, I was not going to sit down with that document. I checked the document for completeness. I signed it, but I had no intention of sitting down like a corporate lawyer and second-guessing it with the intention of changing it. Of course, as Senator Alston knows, the department's original position on this would have been a matter of record and my changes would have been a matter of record. I might also add that to the best of my knowledge no other Minister, certainly in my time in the portfolio, has ever done such a thing.

PARA.TAB: I can just imagine the questions. If I had done that, if in Darwin I had said, off the top of my head, $5 million, as Senator Alston is suggesting, and if after I had done that—and let us get down to the bottom line—the Packer-Murdoch consortium had won it and, even worse, the Packer-Murdoch consortium had been one of the few bids even put in, I know what the questions would have been. `Senator Collins, has your department handled tenders in broadcasting worth hundreds of millions of dollars while you have been in the portfolio?'. Answer—`Yes'. `Have they done it competently and efficiently in accordance with good business practice?'. `Yes'. `Have you ever intervened or altered the process of any previous tender?'. `No'. `To your knowledge has any other Minister done so?'. `No'. `Why did you choose this particular tender for pay TV?'. I am being buried with accusations in the press—and do not think that that sort of thing does not get to you after a while; it does—on absolutely baseless grounds that I was setting up the process myself for the benefit of a certain few. Of course, this would have been said, and Senator Alston knows it.

Was it reasonable of me, under all the circumstances, to have assumed that the department would capably carry out the process of a tender in the way in which it had on every previous occasion that I had been involved with the portfolio. Only a reasonable person—and I am not going to find any across the chamber today—would say `Yes'. Was it reasonable of me, in all of the political circumstances of the time, to treat this tender with particular care and, based on the assumption I have just talked about, take the decision that I was not going to be seen to be interfering in any way?

It is easy for Senator Alston to say, `You could have put in $5 million; it would not have upset anybody'. Do not tell me it would not have. I would have been in here answering questions such as, `On the basis of what advice did you put $5 million in, Senator Collins, when your department did not want to exclude this company or that company? Why was it not $2 million? Why was it not $1 million?'. Of course that would have happened and Senator Alston knows it.

So I think it was reasonable of me. As I said earlier today in Question Time, this is not a very pleasant process for anybody, but I would rather be in here copping flack for not intervening in the department's processes—as far as I am concerned, I can do that with conviction—than trying to defend what I would have thought in terms of real ministerial responsibility was indefensible. Had I taken the decision to interfere in the administration, the mechanics, of a tender process, where I had not done so in respect of any other tender lodged in the department, do not tell me what would have been said in the press. I know perfectly well.

Did I have any reason to believe that they changed the form of process? No. Was the routine that I was used to and to the best of my knowledge had been performed on every other occasion? Where there is substantial change—and how substantial could one get than this—is the department required to specifically seek approval for that variation in process? I have since discovered—and I did not know it until this happened—that there is a requirement in fact to do that within the department and to flag such advice to the secretary. I do not know whether that happened and, of course, the investigation will find that out.

As I said earlier today, this is, in a real sense, a trumped up charge. One thing about this industry—and have a look at it—is that it is absolutely inundated with criticism, inundated with legal action. I have spent a lot of time looking around the world at the central policy question; I have spent a lot of time investigating price based and merit based systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is process. I have spent a lot of time on that, not just here but also around the world, and it is a very interesting examination. The United States has produced some interesting material in this area, particularly with regard to the FAA and things such as air traffic control contracts. On balance, a price based system produces the best value to the public—
—Nobody is arguing about that.

—Can I finish? Comparing a price based system with a merit based system, the former produces the best value to the public. I make these points because everyone is now saying, `You should have assessed viability, et cetera'.
—Rubbish.

—Senator Alston should look at the weekend press, which contains his own statements. How can he sit there with a po-face and deny it? Have a look at the merit based system. At the end of the day, is the merit based system determining viability a better judge of the future financial operation of a company than a price based system? It is not, from what I have seen.

PARA.TAB: I am making these points—and I should point this out to Senator Alston—because this is what the Democrats have been saying. They are involved in this debate. It is not just Senator Alston; the world does not revolve around him. I am making these points because I have seen what the Democrats have said. All I am saying to the Democrats—and they have a view—is that the best result as far as I am concerned is, firstly, to get the best market value of the asset for the public and, secondly, to end up with a viable operator. On balance, I still think that the price based system is better.

The Government adopted the policy decision that the system would be price based and, of course, it was recommendation No. 1 of Senator Alston's report to this Senate on pay TV. I can anticipate what Senator Bourne is going to say but, with the greatest respect, I have a different view to the one she will expound on the merits of the two systems. In all the political circumstances—and that is the real world I live in—there was no way—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did honourable senators see what happened to Tony Staley? I actually went back and had a look at what happened to the first Minister who touched pay TV, not knowing what I would find. It was fascinating to look at. Tony Staley referred the question of pay TV to the ABT. Do honourable senators know what happened? It was an absolute debacle. Tony Staley received written advice from the Attorney-General's Department that the ABT was acting unlawfully. He ignored that advice. The matter went all the way to the High Court, which ruled in favour of the applicants, ruling that it was acting illegally. Tony Staley was censured in the Parliament for ignoring specific advice telling him it was wrong and he was called on to resign. Did he resign? No, he did not resign.

PARA.TAB: Do not think this matter is unique. In a real sense, I have to say, have I behaved with propriety on this issue? I have. Have I behaved responsibly on this issue? I have. Some might now say I have behaved too responsibly in distancing myself from this process. Have I behaved competently on this issue? I believe I have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) for his kind words and apologise in advance because I am about to abuse him. The last phrase in this matter of public importance is one with which no-one could possibly disagree, that is, the one which reads, `the pay TV satellite licence fiasco'. The administration of pay TV in this country has been accident prone, to put it politely, right from the beginning. Let me quote from the Hansard of 13 October last year, when I said:

PARA.TAB: We are concerned that Australia's pay TV policy is becoming as chaotic as was Britain's when subscription television was introduced there in the mid-1980s. The Minister shakes his head—

SPEECH.PARA: which he was doing at the time; now he is nodding—

I hope he is right. The way it looks at the moment is that decisions are made just before the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) goes before television. Decisions are made at meetings of the Centre Left. Decisions are made in the oddest possible places and are then broadcast
. . . and then the Labor Party has to wear it . . . That is the way it looks to the general Australian public.

That is the way it still looks. The tender disaster is just the last in a very long line of disasters that we call pay TV in Australia. As far as we can see, there are three basic reasons for this. The first is that the Minister has taken far too much advice from an immensely deregulatory and `dry' department, his own Department of Transport and Communications. Secondly, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), as I said, has intervened in the most Machiavellian manner with what seems to be almost no background knowledge. I hope somebody can correct me on that, but I think I am right. The third—and the most important—reason for this is that pay TV in Australia is based on section 8 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, legislation which is appallingly flawed and which passed this Parliament only because it was voted for by the Government and the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Let us get back to basics on pay TV. What are the most basic and glaring flaws in the legislation, things that still have to be fixed up right now? Firstly, the role of the ABC has to be looked at. The ABC is mandated under satellite; it is not mandated anywhere else. If we want Australian content in news, current affairs, children's entertainment and light entertainment, we want the ABC in there right from the beginning, no matter what pay TV system starts up.

Secondly, cross-media ownership needs to be looked at. We still believe—I know I have said it about a thousand times in here; I will continue to say it—there is far too much power in the hands of far too few people in Australia in terms of the Australian media. We do not want to see too much foreign ownership. At the moment, foreign ownership is not spelt out in the legislation. What is spelt out in the legislation is that the cross-media rules will apply only to the satellite. Even in the satellite legislation, the cross-media rules are appallingly inadequate. As far as all other terms of delivery of pay TV are concerned, there is nothing in the legislation and there should be. We would like to see foreign ownership rules in the legislation, with the level of foreign ownership being under 35 per cent.

Local content may be the most important part of the legislation. The legislation imposes a 10 per cent Australian program content level despite what all of the witnesses said to the Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services. Every one of the witnesses, including potential bidders, said that they thought 15 per cent or more was appropriate. The Minister stated in his second reading speech that setting the level higher than 10 per cent would be an unnecessary financial burden on those people. We still do not believe that.

I moved an amendment to the Bill to put the level of local content up to 20 per cent initially. I received no support. The level is still at 10 per cent and only for drama. I wanted it to go across the board—not just for drama but for news, current affairs, light entertainment and children's programs. We did not get support on that either. Another of the amendments which I moved would have allowed the ABA, after five years, to look at what whether the local program content should be increased by five per cent or more. Of course, I got no support on that either. All witnesses before the Senate inquiry suggested higher levels of independent Australian production were not only attainable but highly desirable. Not one of the potential bidders expressed the view that higher levels would amount to an unnecessary financial impost.

What about manufacturing content? Manufacturing content should be high, it should be Australian and it should be mandated. There is something in the legislation about manufacturing content in satellite provisions of pay TV. There is nothing in the legislation for any other method of delivery, nothing at all. It should be in there. So far, both the Government and the Opposition have voted for regulatory models which do not adequately protect Australian culture and do not adequately protect Australian jobs. This should be our real concern.

Do we want to be swamped by American news and drama at the expense of our own? I can tell honourable senators now that CNN shows almost nothing of Australia. BBC world television shows almost nothing of Australia. Do we want our children to learn the Sesame Street jingle but not be able to sing `There's a Bear in There'? Of course not. We need Australian children's television, children's entertainment and children's drama. It should be Australian. We do it very, very well and we should be doing on it pay TV, and we should be encouraging that. We should not just be encouraging it but also mandating it in the legislation. Do we want the electronics and the communications work which is going to go with any delivery system for pay TV to go to Australian firms or do we want it to go overseas?

The bungled tendering process really has no bearing on these questions, but it is a mammoth mistake. It has to be fixed and must never happen again. The question to be asked is: was this deliberate? If it was deliberate, whoever in the department was responsible should be sacked. They should go. There should be very strong action taken on that.

If this mistake was not deliberate, we have to find out how it happened and how on earth a tender document missed out one of the most important bits, one of the pieces which is absolutely basic to a tender document. It is so basic, it is like saying, `Did you brush your teeth this morning?'. One does not think about it; it just happens. It involved asking the question: is a deposit required for this tender? One does not think about it; it is just there. Well, it was not there. We have to find out why it was not there. How on earth did it get as far as the Minister's office, let alone his desk, without that being contained in it? I agree that the Minister should have read it, or read it a lot more thoroughly. I can also appreciate that he has thousands of pieces of paper going across his desk every week.
