PARA.TAB: I would point out that the Government is proposing a package of reforms in this area which I believe will improve the processes of this chamber and make for a more reasonable period of sitting time. The routine of business will not be under such a strain; honourable senators will not be under such a strain; and there will be a far more reasonable and sensible modus operandi for the Senate chamber.

Senator Hill needs to accept that there has been a very great imbalance in the sitting times of estimates committees. This is shown in the public hearings and also, to some extent—although I do not consider this a major issue—in the private meetings associated with those hearings. I have taken out some figures for the 1992 Budget sittings which—and the Opposition should seriously consider them—strongly support the case for reform. The figures for the estimates committee hearings and meetings are as follows: Estimates Committee A sat for 20 hours 39 minutes. Estimates Committee B sat for 65 hours. This might have been due not so much to the allocation of departments as to the membership of the committee. The other figures are: Estimates Committee C sat for 29 hours 40 minutes; Estimates Committee D for 14 hours 49 minutes—

TALK.START.PARA: —But that was a quality committee, that one.

—Was Senator Crichton-Browne a member of that committee? Estimates Committee E sat for 25 hours 8 minutes and Estimates Committee F sat for 25 hours 40 minutes. The total sitting time is 181 hours, give or take a few minutes.

PARA.TAB: I believe that any fair-minded person looking at those figures would have to say that there is a clear imbalance in the time taken by estimates committees to examine departments. There is clearly a need for the Government and this chamber to address that imbalance. What the Government has proposed in the motion is an attempt to see that the workload of the estimates committees is evened out so that there is a fair workload across six committees.

That is not easy to do, given the nature of ministerial responsibilities. Obviously, if at all possible we do not want to split ministerial responsibilities across estimates committees. With one exception, that has been achieved in this proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is that one?
—I believe the one exception is arts and administrative services. This has been done in order to provide a balance between the committees.

PARA.TAB: I suppose in any motion like this there is always a little bit of crystal ball gazing. We cannot be absolutely certain, nor would anyone expect, that we will get a precise amount of equivalent time between the committees. I do not think that will happen. But I am absolutely certain that if we adopt the proposal that has been outlined today we will see a much fairer allocation of time. The situation could not be much worse than having Estimates Committee B meet for 65 hours and Estimates Committee D meet for 14 hours 49 minutes. It would not be difficult to find a better and fairer allocation of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is all very interesting but, as I understand it, Senator Faulkner is speaking by leave specifically to answer some questions that Senator Hill raised with him. As I recall, they specifically concern the question of why there are not 10 estimates committees instead of the six that are being proposed. Senator Hill and the rest of us would be interested to hear the answer to that.I do not know that we are terribly interested in the timings that Senator Faulkner is now giving us. He is speaking with leave. We seem to be wasting some time which possibly we could save.
—Senator Faulkner is dealing with the general subject, but I would remind him of the questions that were asked.

—I am trying to set the general framework, which I think is important. Mr President, I apologise for saying that Arts and Administrative Services were split between two committees. The proposal, in fact, includes them in one.
—They are both under D.

—Yes. As Senator Crichton-Browne said, it is an excellent committee and no doubt it will do the job effectively. The Government is attempting to put a proposal before the Senate which means that Ministers can clearly have responsibility to one single committee. For example, I have ministerial responsibility for both Veterans Affairs and Defence Science and Personnel. This particular proposal means that I will be responsible to one estimates committee.
—Which committee is Senator Schacht responsible for?

—I believe Senator Schacht is responsible for Estimates Committee E. If the other proposal before the chamber is accepted, it will mean that, with the assistance of the Parliamentary Secretary, Ministers will have responsibility to one committee. It will mean a streamlining of our processes. There is ample opportunity for all senators in this chamber to play a role on estimates committees. As mentioned in the proposed program of hearings of estimates committees, there is an opportunity for every single senator in this chamber—as we have always had—to follow through his or her interests. But we will not find ourselves in a situation where one estimates committee bogs down the whole procedure and the whole process of the Senate for literally days and days.
—Why not 10?

—Because we can operate perfectly effectively and well with six estimates committees, as we have done for a long time. There is no need to expand the number of committees that we have in this chamber. We can do it perfectly effectively with the number that we have. Take, for example, the area of responsibility that I have with Senator Ray, as the portfolio Minister for Defence. What a preposterous situation to suggest that we have an estimates committee with Senator Ray as the Minister at the table, where I share responsibilities in the same portfolio area and where some areas under discussion are obviously matters that would fall within my area of ministerial responsibility.

PARA.TAB: The proposition that Opposition senators are putting forward is an absolute nonsense. I ask them to consider that example because it is a perfect example of why what they are proposing will not work and is wrong in principle. The answer to the Senate's difficulties is not to increase the number of Senate estimates committees that we have. The answer to the problems that we face in this chamber is to see the Senate committee system and the Senate estimates committees work far more effectively than they are at the moment. That is why the Government is putting forward this positive package of proposals to streamline the procedures of this chamber.

I really do think Opposition senators need to examine their own behaviour on these estimates committees. They ought to ask themselves why Estimates Committee B goes for 65 hours in duration when Estimates Committee D can deal with a very substantial workload in 14 hours and 49 minutes. Opposition senators know why. It is because people abuse the process and try to score points off defenceless public servants, and so it goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that logic you'd wind them up.
—That is what those opposite are trying to do.
—No, we are trying to further opportunities.

—They are putting forward a proposition that clearly will not work. It has to be associated with ministerial authority in this chamber. I will give another example—Senator Richardson's new ministerial responsibility and mine, as Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite are proposing a change to the way these committees have operated that clearly will not work, and they are doing it only because one or two people in this chamber use the estimates committees as their only vehicle for self-promotion, and to harangue public servants and to see, hour after hour, officers of the Commonwealth of Australia wasting their time out the back doing nothing. Those opposite know that that is true. Every one of them, with the exception—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your bad management—to have us sitting here all night.

—What does Senator Hill mean, it is my bad management? I have not been Manager of Government Business when there has been an estimates committee hearing. I am really looking forward to it. It will be a terrific experience. I really am looking forward to it, let me assure Senator Hill. It will be an absolute bundle of laughs, no doubt.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that there are only two or three Opposition senators who, in their heart of hearts, would be fair dinkum about opposing this proposition. They all know that they dislike, as much as Government senators dislike, wasting hour after hour on useless pieces of alleged interrogation, and they know that it is time wasting extraordinaire; it is time wasting writ large.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that your judgment?
—It is my judgment and it is Senator Hill's judgment too. He knows that there is no support for that sort of activity on his side.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I thought we were dealing with notices of motion Nos 10 and 11. The Minister seems to be talking about some other motion. Certainly, what he is talking about does not have relevance to Nos 10 and 11. I ask you to order the Minister to speak to those two motions or otherwise explain to us how what he is saying is relevant to the issues before us.
—It is becoming a very long contribution, but I take it that the Minister is giving reasons why there should be six estimates committees and not 10.

—Let me conclude my remarks. The proposal of the Government is a more logical, a more systematic and a more reasonable proposition than the one we currently have. To extend the number of estimates committees would be, unfortunately, to make an almost impossible situation totally impossible—one that no reasonable senator would want to live with.

PARA.TAB: The answer is to keep the existing number of committees; to even out the workload so that it is fair; for senators who are members of estimates committees to behave in a reasonable way on those estimates committees; for all of us to agree on a package of reforms that will make life in this Senate for senators, as human beings, a great deal more reasonable; and for the political process and the Parliament to work a great deal better than they have before.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not claim to be the brightest soul in this chamber, but I did not understand a single word Senator Faulkner said.
—It was very clear.

—I invite Senator West to be the next speaker and ask her whether she would be kind enough to enlighten us as to the compelling reasons for having six estimates committees rather than eight or 10. I do not believe that question was addressed. Senator Faulkner came into the chamber equipped with a prepared address—which no doubt he developed whilst walking around the park at lunch time—and we were going to get it regardless of what the question was, and get it we did.

PARA.TAB: Let me observe two things to start with. The first is that the Labor Party's numbers have diminished in this chamber, and I suspect it is a long term pattern which we will see continuing into the future. Secondly, the number of Ministers in the Senate has increased from six to 10. There has been a very significant increase in ministerial representation in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of years ago there were eight.

—Yes, and it was sunny yesterday. What is Senator Coates trying to say to me? I do not oppose there being 10 Ministers in the Senate; in fact, I think it has a great deal of virtue. But at the same time that there has been an increase in membership, there has been an attempt by the Government to restrict the number of estimates committees to six and to reduce the number of standing committees from nine to seven. There seems to be no logical reason for that. As I struggle to come to grips with Senator Faulkner's explanation—
—The logical reason is they are reducing numbers. They worry that they cannot man them.

—Senator Hill is right. It is beyond me to understand how maintaining the status quo of six estimates committees will reduce the amount of time spent on estimates committees. All Senator Faulkner has done is put the pea under a different thimble. The Government still has the same number of departments and the same number of estimates committees, but it has increased the number of Ministers who could now be servicing and appearing before extra estimates committees. In no way has the Government restricted the time that will be spent at estimates committee hearings.

PARA.TAB: It is no great secret that because of the Government's diminishing numbers—and three-quarters of Senator Faulkner's colleagues have been given some higher promotion—it does not have the numbers to service the committees. That is why those opposite wanted to reduce the number of members serving on standing committees from eight to six. The only thing that stopped that was that the Democrats also wanted a spot on the committees and, when it became obvious to the Government that they could have that only at the expense of the Government, the number then went back to eight.

This has nothing to do with scrutiny of government, scrutiny of the Parliament, or scrutiny of government expenditure. It is all about the Labor Party's fun sport and that is numbers. The Labor Party is not concerned about proper scrutiny of the Parliament, of expenditure or of legislation. It is concerned about extending the number of committees to that which it can reasonably accommodate. After that point, scrutiny is irrelevant. It is inconsequential. It is not to matter and it is certainly not to count.

If there was one thing that the Western Australian royal commission investigating the conduct of the Labor Government of that State showed, it was an ever growing need for proper scrutiny of government conduct. There was a raft of recommendations from that royal commission which called for the Parliament to have greater capacity and greater powers to scrutinise the conduct of the Western Australian Government. This Government has learnt nothing from that royal commission. It is seeking to retard even further the capacity of the Parliament to scrutinise the legislation.

Frankly, I find it obscene to have a Minister of the Crown, a servant of the people, telling the Parliament that proper scrutiny is a waste of time. I find it obscene for a Minister emotionally and subjectively to claim that one senator's diligence and dedication is a waste of time and irrelevant, and that the lack of attention to detail, lack of concern and lack of regard and lack of vigilance of another senator is the sort of conduct that ought to be followed by everybody else. I still do not understand how increasing the number of estimates committees will in any way increase the workload. It will simply do one thing, that is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Spread the load.
—It will spread the load and provide for greater scrutiny. I still have not come to grips with what Ministers have what responsibility in this Government.
—I thought Senator Faulkner was a Parliamentary Secretary, so you are doing better than me.

—One has to come into the chamber and see who sits on the front bench to find out. If we look at Estimates Committee A, it seems that both Senator Evans and Senator Cook have responsibilities. If we look at Estimates Committee B, it appears that Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner both have responsibilities. If we look at Estimates Committee C, it seems that Senator Richardson and Senator Crowley both have responsibilities. Estimates Committee D, E and F are covered by Senator McMullan, Senator Collins and Senator Schacht, and Senator Bolkus has Estimates Committee F. In other words, we have two Ministers for three of the estimates committees. We were told this morning that we were going to have a Secretary, a new little boy is going to come along representing a Minister at one of the estimates committees and that the Minister will not be available at all.

PARA.TAB: There is no reason why we cannot extend the number of estimates committees to eight. I say to Senator Faulkner that I do not know whether the reallocation of portfolios under the various committees makes a lot of sense. Frankly, that is the least of my concerns. My concern is to make sure we have a Minister before each committee and that we have before us the bureaucrats. We need the correct number of estimates committees so there can be proper, responsible and diligent scrutiny of the conduct of the Government and expenditure of taxpayers' funds.

I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment to Senator Faulkner's motion which will increase the number of estimates committees from six to eight. I have not argued for 10, although there is a very persuasive argument for that. The Democrats have always quite properly argued that the Senate is a proper forum for proper scrutiny. I commend the Democrats for the number of occasions on which they have called for pieces of legislation and matters of importance to be referred to select committees. I implore the Democrats to embrace the proposal I am putting forward by way of my amendment. I understand the estimates committees are sitting for only one day.

There is no logical reason why we cannot have eight estimates committees. After all, we have 10 Ministers, so we can have one Minister present at each committee. We on this side of the chamber are certainly happy to provide our share of the required number of senators, who will properly discharge their responsibilities in scrutinising legislation and the Government program before the estimates committee. I find it vaguely obscene that the number of standing committees in this Parliament—

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it grossly obscene, Senator Faulkner, that the number of estimates committees, the number of standing committees and the number of select committees is limited by the capacity of the Labor Government to man them. That is the only criteria, the only argument, that is put up. I will be appalled if Senator Faulkner gets support for his nonsensical proposition from any other party or from the Independents simply because the Government does not have enough diligent senators, or because they all have other fancy jobs or they are all too damn lazy to service these committees.
—Who won the election, Noel?

—Without going on a side excursion, I am asked by Senator Bolkus, from somebody else's seat, who won the election. I have not spent much time visiting past the border but I know that the Labor Party was crushed in Western Australia. If that result had been repeated right across Australia, there would have been an overwhelming victory for the Liberal Party. In fact, if the performance of every other State had been repeated in New South Wales alone, it would have been a crushing victory for the Liberal Party. I remind Senator Bolkus that only one State saved its tail. It will not happen next time.
—I think we are a little off the topic.
—Forgive me, Mr Deputy President, for diverting from the essence of the reason why I am standing.
—I am very reasonable.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I ask the responsible members of this chamber, other than the coalition, to support this proposal. It is obscene and grossly improper that the number of committees is dictated by the number of members of the Labor Party. It is wrong that the capacity of the Parliament of Australia to scrutinise, examine, consider and deliberate over legislation extends only to the capacity of the Government to provide its share of numbers to service these committees. I move:

PARA.TAB: Leave out all words after "That", insert:
(a)notwithstanding anything contained in standing order 26(1), the following estimates committees be appointed: Estimates Committees A, B, C, D, E, F, G and H; and
(b)the estimates committees consider proposed expenditure in relation to departments in accordance with a resolution of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take a short time to provide some of the other reasons that Senator Crichton-Browne was seeking as to why the appropriate number of estimates committees is six. I am not going to go as far as to suggest that members of the Opposition are being deliberately obtuse about this matter; I suspect that their memory has lapsed. Let me remind everyone that one of the reasons why there have been six estimates committees for 20 years is that there was a general agreement a long time ago—and that agreement has continued—that the appropriate number of committees to be meeting at any one time was three. One of the reasons for that was that that was the appropriate number that Hansard could service at any one time. I think that is still the case, especially when the House of Representatives is sitting.
—We blame Hansard now, do we?

—I am trying to put some reasonable arguments forward. Those who have been here over that time will recall that one of the reasons was that the number of committees that Hansard could service at any one time was three. That especially applies when the House of Representatives is sitting at the same time. Another reason that is a more up-to-date one is that that is also the maximum number of committees that the Sound and Vision Office can televise at one time.

PARA.TAB: Last year there was a particular sitting of estimates committees—I think it was at the same time as the House of Representatives was sitting—and Sound and Vision was proposing to televise only two of the three estimates committees that were sitting at one time. We had Senator Bishop going right off her tree about how disgraceful it was that one of the estimates committees was not being televised. If there were to be eight estimates committees, presumably we would be talking about having four meeting at any one time. That, therefore, would put extra pressure on Hansard and decisions would have to be made about the number of committees that could be televised at one time.

As far as the servicing of committees by senators from either side is concerned, the Opposition has quite successfully managed to have different people attending one estimates committee at different times depending on the portfolio being considered. The allocation of portfolios to estimates committees is, as Senator Faulkner has said, purely a matter of balancing the amount of time that ought to be needed for them all to be through at about the same time.

The Opposition's need to have different shadow spokespersons attending and different interests reflected because of the mixture of portfolios that are looked after by different Ministers has been perfectly adequately catered for by the way in which it has had different membership for different portfolios within the same committee.

The main point about the six committees is that only three can sit at any one time for those servicing reasons that I have mentioned, and also for the interests of senators who want to participate in them, especially Opposition senators. People have complained that it is difficult enough for people who want to deal with one particular matter at one committee and also attend another one when there are three sitting at the one time. If four were sitting at the one time those complaints about the difficulty of programming to satisfy a variety of interests would be even greater.

One can go to the other extreme and say, `Let's have 19 estimates committees and call them A to P', or whatever it turns out to be, `and have one per portfolio'. That would be perfectly okay as long as we ended up with an agreement that there would be some limited amount of time for each one. It is purely a mechanical means of ensuring that everyone knows when a particular committee is meeting and that excessive duplication of facilities is not required. Six has always been, and I am sure will continue to be, the appropriate number, because three is the appropriate number for committees to be meeting at once.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief comments about the motion moved by my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne. The debate touches on a wider issue which is particularly important to the Parliament, to this Senate and to the public at large. A range of proposals have been put forward by the coalition to make some substantial reforms in the procedures of this Parliament. Essentially, each of the reforms which we put forward, including the reforms that Senator Crichton-Browne has put forward, encourage more scrutiny of government actions and legislation. Each of those measures—there are probably four or five measures relating to Question Time, Chairs of committees, estimates committees and so forth—have as their essence the need to improve the performance of this Parliament and, among other things, to subject government actions to greater scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: I have just come into the chamber and I am not sure how the Democrats will be voting on this issue. I rather hope that as we start the new session of Parliament, and as we have a new leader of the Australian Democrats, we will have this same commitment to seeing how we can improve the performance of the legislative arm of government and how we can improve the scrutiny of government actions. I would have thought that, much as it is part of our own philosophy, it should equally be part of the philosophy of the new leadership of the Australian Democrats. That is why I strongly support the motion moved by Senator Crichton-Browne to increase the number of estimates committees.

Senator Coates raised some cogent points. I do not say that increasing the number of Senate committees from six to 10 will not raise some of the issues raised by Senator Coates, such as resources and timing. I happen to like attending a number of the estimates committees. I am well aware of the problems of getting between the committees as issues are raised and as the sections that I am particularly concerned with come on for debate.

I recognise that Senator Coates raised fair points, but they are points that reasonable people can sit down and deal with. I pick up Senator Coates's point that certainly on our side of the Parliament there may well be a trade-off between being able to go around between a number of committees and ensuring that a larger number of Senate estimates committees are in session. Perhaps we would have to put up with four rather than three sitting at once. Those issues can be dealt with.

We now have 10 Ministers in this chamber. The Government now has the capacity to require Ministers to attend these estimates committees more so than they have done in the past. We therefore have an opportunity, I would have thought, to deal with the sorts of problems that Senator Coates has raised and to, above all, increase the scrutiny of government actions.

What often seems happen at the start of a Parliament is that everyone talks about parliamentary reform. I see that even the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is starting to trumpet parliamentary reform. That is a good thing. We should be testing Mr Keating and his colleagues to see how far they are prepared to go. I believe Senator Crichton-Browne's proposal is part of the wider debate on whether we are prepared to listen to the Australian people and ensure that the executive arm of government is more closely scrutinised in its activities.

The Democrats should think very carefully about not supporting this type of measure. Logic shows—and we now have the numbers on this side of the Parliament—that a greater number of estimates committees will provide a greater amount of time and a greater ability for senators to be involved in scrutinising government actions.

I hope that when this measure comes to the vote we will see a commitment by the Australian Democrats to improving the functioning of this chamber and the accountability of government. If they do not wish to follow down that path, we are entitled to hear good, clear reasons why they do not believe greater scrutiny and accountability should be imposed on the Government. There is no possibility of such a thing happening in the other place where the Government has the numbers.

A particular responsibility now rests with this Senate chamber. I believe that we have put forward some very major initiatives in relation to Question Time, estimates committees and the standing committees which would amount to a very significant reform of this chamber. Reform is one of the first tests we all have in this Parliament. We understand that the Government is anxious not to complicate its task any further. While we may not applaud that, we can certainly recognise that this will be the response of the Government. But there is no need for it to be the response of the Australian Democrats.

Senator Crichton-Browne's motion is a genuine attempt to bring about a reform to the estimates committee process and one to which we are committed. We on our side will certainly ensure that senators and Ministers, now 10 in all, will attend estimates committees. The Parliamentary Secretary, Senator Sherry, has assured us that he also will be attending. We have the numbers to do it. I urge all senators, particularly Senator Coulter and his colleagues, to support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kemp for underscoring on a broadcast day the crucial and important role played by the Australian Democrats. This is typically one of those situations where the Government has put forward a motion for having six estimates committees. The Opposition has tabled an amendment suggesting that there be eight estimates committees. As Senator Kemp said, the determination of that amendment will depend very much on the way in which we, the Democrats, vote. I again thank Senator Kemp for underscoring the important role that we play in this place.

PARA.TAB: I agree with the Opposition to the extent that we certainly underline the very great importance of scrutiny of government. We believe, perhaps even more vehemently than the Opposition, that too much power has come to reside with executive government and that decisions are made extremely narrowly. In the recent election, we saw the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) exclusively make decisions which even his own party did not know about until they were announced to the public. We have seen the Prime Minister make decisions on the run by way of press release. Again, members of his own Government—his own Ministers—did not know exactly what that decision was until they read about it in the paper or heard about it on the radio. That way of running the country is extremely objectionable.

As Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out, the shenanigans in Western Australia with the Burke Government and succeeding Labor governments left a great deal to be desired in relation to accountability. The Executive, or a small group within the Executive, was able to run what we now know were extremely corrupt practices, as we know from the inquiry.

Having said all that, we observe that no section of the portfolios will be excluded. Irrespective of whether we have six or eight committees, all the portfolios will come up for scrutiny. Presumably the Opposition, in considering how it will deal with questions to Ministers and senior public servants in these estimates committees, will have the opportunity to examine each of these people and each of the issues. The number, variety and nature of the questions and so on that they will ask will not be in any way limited by the existence of six or eight committees. It seems to me that the question of scrutiny as such is really not an issue.

One of the very important issues—Senator Coates touched on this, but I would like to extend it—is that each time we suggest the establishment of a select committee, for instance, one question that always arises is whether that committee can be serviced and what the costs of servicing it will be. The same thing applies with respect to the estimates committees. The costs of creating two additional committees is not inconsiderable.

Senator Coates touched on the cost of Hansard. If we have to expand the Hansard services and these committees only meet for a brief time several times each year, what will happen to those staff at other times? Will we expand the rest of the committee system to ensure, as the Opposition frequently claims, that the staff is effectively and efficiently used? Of course, other staff service these committees. As Senator Coates mentioned, video and audio staff will be required so that those senators who are moving between committees or who are otherwise engaged can at least know what is going on in the various committees.

In times of significant economic stringency and when both the Government and the Opposition are talking about decreasing staff and making everybody's work more efficient and more effective, it seems passing strange that in this particular case the Opposition wants to increase the number of committees from six to eight. I do not think the question of proper scrutiny was raised, because all these matters, all these portfolios, all these Ministers and all these staff and so on will be brought before the committee and it is well within the capability of any senator to ask questions within the existing six estimates committees. For those reasons, the Democrats will be opposing the amendment and supporting the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect we are wasting our time on this debate. I suspect the debate was lost during Senator Hill's speech when Senator Faulkner went over and had a chat with Senator Coulter. I suspect from that time onwards the deal had been done.

PARA.TAB: That is not going to prevent me from trying once more to convince the chamber of the correctness of Senator Crichton-Browne's amendment to the motion. The Opposition gave Senator Faulkner leave to explain to us why there should not be 10 or eight estimates committees. We got a very long discourse on the fact that, because some people are longwinded, Senator Faulkner thought that by having six estimates committees this problem would be stopped. I cannot understand how having six estimates committees, as we had last time, is going to stop people being longwinded. I could not follow any of Senator Faulkner's arguments and nor could anyone else on this side of the chamber.

I am grateful to Senator Coates for at least raising a couple of arguments that we could follow and which did have a smidgin of validity about them. He raised problems that we can think about and which I am sure can be overcome.

The Australian Democrats is the party that used to be—and I emphasise used to be—in Don Chipp's day the party that was very big on scrutiny and on keeping the government honest. The Democrats have completely fallen away from this objective of their party and that is why they got such a poor vote in the last election. The people of Australia understand that they are now no more than toadies to the Labor Party. They are people who are more left wing than the Labor Party. Whenever I say they should go and join the Labor Party, the Labor Party members say, `Even our left faction is not as bad as the Democrats'.

They have certainly got away from their original reason for being—that was to keep the government honest and to make sure that legislation was scrutinised. I suppose from the Democrats' point of view—and it is important that their few remaining voters understand this—it does not matter to them whether there are six or eight estimates committees that they do not attend. They are not terribly big on scrutiny when it comes to estimates committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are never there.

—That is what I am saying, Senator Panizza. They may as well not be there on six as not be there on eight—it is the same thing. They are not terribly good, but they do roll over and agree with the Government whenever we try to put up sensible reforms to assist in the scrutiny process.

PARA.TAB: The reason for these sensible reforms is that there is limited time. If the system is spread a bit wider and extra Ministers are allowed in, as Senator Crichton-Browne wisely proposed, then we can get through those particular areas of government work much quicker. Therefore, we would not have those long sessions because the number of departments considered by each committee could well be shortened.

I can suggest to Senator Faulkner and the Labor Party, without trying in any way to insert names in Senator Crichton-Browne's motion, certain things that could be done. In Estimates Committee A the Government could give Senator Evans responsibility for Prime Minister and Cabinet and Foreign Affairs and Trade and leave Primary Industries and Energy to be considered by a separate estimates committee. Primary Industries and Energy is a very important department to be considered by the estimates committees but one which in recent times has not been scrutinised properly because we have simply run out of time and we have not been able to properly question the Government on those sorts of things.

The Government could split the work of Estimates Committee B. Senator Ray could have responsibility for Defence and Senator Faulkner could be left with the others. Senator Faulkner is going to be hard-pressed answering questions relating to Veterans' Affairs and Employment, Education and Training. It would be great to have Senator Ray for Defence because he knows what he is doing and he could get it over and done with quickly.

Estimates Committee E is apparently only going to have one Minister appearing before it. I assume that will be Senator Schacht because Senator Collins will be trying to fix up the fiasco into which he has got himself in the communications area. Senator Schacht should probably—

SPEECH.PARA: I represent Christmas Island in the Senate and have had the opportunity in the last year to visit Christmas Island on two occasions. The community on Christmas Island is undergoing a number of very important changes that have arisen from various initiatives taken by the Government and from legislation that has been passed through this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I am sure a number of honourable senators will recall that the Territories Law Reform Act was enacted in 1992 and consequent to that the administration of both the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island has undergone major and important changes. Many of those have been difficult changes for the residents of the two separate communities. Christmas Island, which this particular report addresses, has seen a number of changes to its municipal administration. The new shire council was, in effect, constituted by the territories law reform legislation. It is now operating and assumes responsibility for the Christmas Island Services Corporation which provides many of those municipal functions.

It is important to recognise that two significant events are taking place on Christmas Island. The first is the development by Indonesian investors of a casino on the island. A casino with a capital investment of approximately $60 million is currently under construction. In the latter part of this year I will be watching very carefully the Government's estimates of the income that it will derive from the various royalties and agreements resulting from the operation of that new casino.

I am certainly aware that the shire council believes the funding arrangements made for municipal services on that island should be reviewed. In fact, it is asking for a percentage of the earnings that will be derived from the casino operations to fund many of its operations. That figure is of course very different from the figures set forth in this particular report of the Christmas Island Services Corporation for the year ended 30 June 1992.

The second issue that is impacting on the island community is the major rebuilding program of the Commonwealth Government. From memory, the figure committed by the Government in the first five-year phase of that rebuilding program is well in excess of $40 million. Naturally, the construction and commercial activity that is taking place is very important.

The community of Christmas Island is, of course, very small. There are approximately 1,300 residents on the island, many of whom take up their residency as former citizens of Malaysia, principally, who were attracted to the island by employment with the phosphate mine on the island itself. Of course, there are now many other employers on the island—principally in the government arena of the National Parks and Wildlife Service which very properly carries out a national park function on the island. There is a very viable small business and commercial sector that is operating and has been stimulated by the development activities of both the casino and the Government's rebuilding program. Of course, a number of other people have also been attracted to the island.

This is an important report because it, in effect, flags out the old government era of administration in which the principal economic activity of the island was provided by government in one form or another and essentially underpinned the phosphate mining. So it is important that we note this report as the final one of the old regime and look carefully at subsequent developments on Christmas Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the coalition's spokesman on local government I was interested to read the final report of the Christmas Island Services Corporation and to note from it that, as from 1 July last year, the functions and responsibilities previously conducted by the corporation have been taken over by a local authority in the form of the Christmas Island Shire Council.

PARA.TAB: In speaking to this report, I simply want to acknowledge that, from all reports, the new shire council on Christmas Island is operating very effectively and responsibly. I understand that there is a sharp learning curve for members of the council, who for the first time are becoming involved in local government as a shire council under the auspices of the Western Australian local government legislation.

I am very pleased to hear that the Christmas Island Shire Council has become a member of the Western Australian Municipal Association, which is the local government association in Western Australia, and is also part of the WAMA purchasing group organised by the Western Australian Municipal Association. The Western Australia Municipal Association has helped as much as it has been able, which I understand is quite considerably, with the new shire council organisation. WAMA has sent some of its officers to Christmas Island and is doing its bit to ensure that the Christmas Island Shire Council becomes part of the mainstream of local government in Western Australia.

I wish the Christmas Island Shire Council all the very best as it enters into this new jurisdiction. I look forward to following its progress in the years ahead and to actually making contact with the council in the not too distant future.

SPEECH.PARA: This report into the Aboriginals benefit trust account, which affects the mining royalty equivalents paid in the Northern Territory, is a very important report because it provides the basis not only for the administration of the four land councils operating in the Northern Territory but also for a series of benefits paid to Aborigines, again in the Northern Territory, under various provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act. PARA.TAB: The distribution of the funds is very important. As I mentioned, a significant proportion of that money is made available to the administration of the respective land councils. If the land councils find that the funds that they receive as a right under the legislation are insufficient to meet their operating costs, they make application to the Minister for top-up funds under the provision of the Aboriginals benefit trust account.

I am always critical of the fact that these funds are approved by the Minister and provided for the additional administrative costs of the land councils in addition to those automatically made available by the legislation. When I say I am critical, I mean that I am critical because that takes away from the funds that are then available for the community benefit of Aborigines in a more direct manner and, in effect, they are being applied for administrative purposes. I have not yet had the opportunity to assess and look in detail at all of this report which was tabled here only this morning. I was concerned in looking at the report of the previous year to note that very significant funds had been pre-committed for the purchase of Aboriginal owned pastoral properties which, in effect, compromised future benefits that could be paid and made available. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The review of the operation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act is a very interesting document. It has a very strong connection with the amendments recently announced by the Government in relation to the operations of the ATSIC Act.

PARA.TAB: It is very interesting to note that, in very many important aspects, what the Labor Party Government has done is simply learnt yet again from the policy which the Liberal and National parties put out at the last election. What is said in this report and in the action that the Government has announced in recent times is simply an endorsement of what our then shadow Minister, Mr Michael Wooldridge, put up to the people of Australia at the last election as our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander policy. Specifically, the Government—and this report makes mention of it—has adopted our proposal to have an office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs to give independent policy advice to the Minister.

There is, of course, a difference between the way in which the Labor Party has introduced this proposal and the way in which we did it. We did it after nine months of consultation, after a discussion paper had been put out and after Dr Wooldridge had had very lengthy discussions with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups. The Labor Party has simply made the announcement and lumped it upon these Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders.

The second proposal stolen by the Government from our election policy—already on the second day of the Parliament the Government is taking over the proposals that we put at the last election—is the reduction in the number of regional councils from 60 to 36. This is referred to on page 25, item 5 of the report. Another proposal that we put up and the Government has now adopted is to have commissioners working full-time and for a salary. We also proposed that regional chairmen should act full-time and on a salary; again, a proposal that has been adopted by the Government. In our policy we have also proposed that decisions should be made at regional council level rather than in the central government in Canberra. That has also been taken over by the Government.

The Government still has a couple of other things to do to legislate correctly in so far as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is concerned in accordance with our policies. Still left to be adopted is our proposal for enhanced accountability. I would certainly urge the Government to look at our proposals in that regard and adopt them in future.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has bipartisan support; certainly it has the support of the Liberal and National parties. However, I should sound a note of warning. It will only get that bipartisan support for so long as it acts responsibly. I was distressed to learn during the campaign that one of its commissioners was promoting some grossly inaccurate statements about our policies, suggesting that petrol and medicines would go up under our GST, when everybody knew that petrol would fall by 26c a litre in cost and that there was to be no GST on medicines. We were rather concerned to see a responsible commissioner going around promoting this sort of Labor Party propaganda.

Although commissioners should have a view on matters of current debate, we hope that they will at least express their view in accordance with the facts and not in line with political propaganda that has been distributed around at the time. Having said that, we continue to offer our bipartisan support to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. We think that the amendments proposed and referred to this in report go a long way towards making the commission even more effective. We wish it continuing success.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch at 12.45 p.m. on this day, which seems a long time ago, I was developing a very important point in this debate, that is, although the Keating Government has been re-elected for a second term, a number of other senators and members of the Opposition were elected to this Parliament who have a very important job to do, even though we are not sitting, as we would like to be, on the other side of the chamber. That job is to scrutinise the performance of this Government and the expenditure of taxpayers' money, to ensure that taxpayers' money is being expended in a proper way and that the objectives of the Government, the objectives of the Parliament, are being met by the bureaucracy.

PARA.TAB: I made the point earlier in the day that it has been widely reported, particularly by the press gallery, that the power of Mr Keating, in his position as Leader of the Government and Prime Minister of Australia, has been enhanced by the result of the election. It is, of course, more important for the Parliament to thoroughly use its powers of scrutiny, and the estimates committee process is crucial to this.

We are debating whether or not it is appropriate for the Senate to agree that a Parliamentary Secretary should perform the duties of a Minister before an estimates committee. The particular estimates committee that we are talking about deals with the primary industries portfolio. There are people across Australia who are involved in the wool industry, in particular, and a number of other rural industries in Queensland who will be very seriously affected by the decisions and the expenditure of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

I would expect that the drought package, which was recently announced by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), will come up for consideration in the Supplementary Estimates. I guess the way in which money is allocated through the rural assistance scheme and the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation will also be considered by that estimates committee. I think it is entirely appropriate and quite proper for our constituents to have their concerns raised by their senators from either side of this chamber, and answers given by a Minister and not merely by a Parliamentary Secretary.

In his contribution to the debate earlier this day, Senator Coulter said that he supported many of the arguments of the Opposition, particularly those put by Senator Bishop. He put a number of other arguments to the Senate which were in favour of the Opposition's view on this motion moved by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner). Even Senator Coulter made the point that we would not want to see this becoming a precedent.

What the Australian Democrats would be doing by supporting this motion is reinforcing the precedent that was created in the last session when the Senate agreed to Senator McMullan taking on responsibilities before an estimates committee. As the Democrats are supporting this motion tonight, they will be adding to that precedent. I am slightly perplexed by Senator Coulter's logic in saying that he does not want to create a precedent but that he is going to go along with it because it is only a sessional order and it applies only to one Parliamentary Secretary. The motion states that any senator appointed as a Parliamentary Secretary under the Parliamentary Secretaries Act may exercise these powers. If the Prime Minister decides from time to time to appoint more Parliamentary Secretaries, Senator Coulter's line of argument is further diminished.

The Opposition needs to be even more diligent than it has been in the past in scrutinising the Government, particularly through the estimates committee process. In the intervening hours between my earlier contribution to the debate and now, we have had a detailed and often heated debate about the role of estimates committees and the number of hours that some estimates committees take to scrutinise government expenditure and the Forward Estimates.
Page 124 of a recent publication from the United States entitled Reinventing Government by David Osborne and Ted Gaebler reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a truism in government that the amount of money in a line item is inversely related to the amount of time the legislature spends debating it.

I think many people who have spent many hours on estimates committees would very much agree with that quote by those two eminent American legislators and academics. It is very important that senators spend a lot of time and are very diligent in going about their work on estimates committees. I do not think one can judge the effectiveness of that time by the number of hours that an estimates committee sits. However, if the Minister and the bureaucrats who are advising the Minister do not perform their functions properly, that scrutiny cannot take place effectively either.

PARA.TAB: It is incumbent upon honourable senators on both sides of the chamber to take that job very seriously. The Parliament has a crucial role to fulfil in this area. We know the Prime Minister's views about the role of the Senate. He would like to see us abolished; he has made that quite clear. The platform of the Labor Party has also, from time to time, made that quite clear.

It is incumbent upon all senators to take the job of legislative review, and particularly review of government expenditure through the Estimates process, extremely seriously because, in the end, we are one of the few real, powerful checks and balances upon the expenditures of government. If we do not do the job properly, no-one else will do it. With those words, I urge the Senate to oppose the motion moved by the Manager of Government Business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on this matter. I preface my remarks by expressing similar comments to those which some of my colleagues have made today: I wish no ill upon the person we are referring to, my Tasmanian colleague Senator Sherry. Any comments I make do not relate to him in particular but to the Opposition's position on this matter.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Campbell and speakers before me have pointed out, the estimates committees play a very important part in the role of this Senate. Perhaps the Opposition takes this matter a lot more seriously because it is, by nature, the role of the Opposition to question and query not only the Ministers but also staff and departments. This year, for the first time in the six years I have been here, we on this side of the chamber had to have a ballot to decide which of us could be members on some of the estimates committees.

Senators on this side of the chamber are keen to be in a position where they can look at the expenditure and see where money is being wasted, to keep the Ministers on their toes but, more importantly, to keep the bureaucrats on their toes. Let us face it, it is an important part of the functions of this chamber to do just that. That being the case—the importance that is placed upon Estimates—it is also very important that the person responsible for a particular department be the person who appears before an estimates committee to be queried.

Other honourable senators on this side of the chamber have made the point very strongly today that Ministers should be available to appear at estimates committee hearings, and there is no reason why they should not be. The Government now has 10 Ministers in the Senate. Surely some of those Ministers could make themselves available to give the estimates committees the appropriate status. With all due respect to my colleague Senator Sherry, the fact that he is a Parliamentary Secretary would make it seem that he would not have the clout, the experience or the rapport with heads of departments and agencies that a Minister would have. I also find it rather peculiar that the Parliamentary Secretaries have had bestowed upon them the title of `the Honourable'. I would have thought that, given the attitude of the Labor Party members towards this chamber and some of its traditions, they would not see fit to bestow upon themselves the title of `the Honourable'.

I also noted this morning the point made by Senator Bishop that Parliamentary Secretaries receive the lurks and perks of the office, which would include more staff and, therefore, more government expenditure. Senator O'Chee made a point about Senator Cook being very uncomfortable last year when questioned about genetic material and related matters to do with his portfolio. It is the responsibility of the Minister in this chamber representing a department or representing a Minister in the other house to be present at the estimates committee hearings. I feel so strongly about it, having heard my colleagues talking this morning, that I now move the following amendment to Senator Faulkner's motion:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of paragraph (1), add "or represent a Minister before a Senate estimates committee".
That would make the first part of the motion read:

Any Senator appointed a Parliamentary Secretary under the Parliamentary Secretaries Act 1980 may exercise the powers and perform the functions conferred upon Ministers by the procedures of the Senate, but may not be asked or answer questions which may be put to Ministers under standing order 72(1) or represent a Minister before a Senate estimates committee.

(a) The Australian Science and Technology Council was established as a statutory authority on 28 February 1979 under the Australian Science and Technology Act 1978. The statutory functions of the Council as set out in the enabling legislation are:
the advancement of scientific knowledge;
the development and application of science and technology in relation to the furtherance of the national well-being;
the adequacy, effectiveness and overall balance of scientific and technological activities in Australia;
the identification and support of new ideas in science and technology likely to be of national importance;
the practical development and application of scientific discoveries;
the fostering of scientific and technological innovation in industry; and
the means of improving efficiency in the use of resources by the application of science and technology.

ASTEC is empowered to operate by conducting inquiries, gathering information, engaging consultants, appointing committees and producing reports. ANSWER.PARA: Environment

PARA.TAB: In July 1992, the Council produced the briefing paper `Women: the Invisible Partners in Ecologically Sustainable Development' as a background document for community response to the Federal Government's initiatives on ESD and greenhouse issues.

The NWCC participated in roundtable consultations and in late December 1992, following further discussion at Commonwealth and State levels, the Federal Government released its National Strategy for Ecologically Sustainable Development. PARA.TAB: A grant of $6,000 was approved from NWCC's Project Budget to employ a consultant to collect information, via a phone-in, on the arrangements of working parents with sick children, who are unable to utilise their usual child care arrangements. The phone-in was held over three days, from Friday 12 June to Sunday 14 June 1992 with over 40 volunteers (including interpreters) answering phones.

An interim report summarising the outcomes of the phone-in and related research was launched at a seminar later in the year which included representatives from Federal and State Governments, unions, employer federations, corporations, small businesses, and members of the public. The final report titled Caring for Sick Children-How Working Mothers Cope includes recommendations from the seminar.

PARA.TAB: The Council sponsored the forum `Women and Enterprise Bargaining: Who Benefits?', gathering together over 250 people interested in the development of industrial relations relating to enterprise bargaining and labour market flexibility with particular reference on women. The objective of the forum was to develop strategies for improving the status of women in employment in Australia in the new industrial situation. The forum aimed to achieve proper recognition of women's skills, pay equity and a balance between work and family life.
A comprehensive report which includes spoken and invited papers and recommendations from the Enterprising Bargaining Forum has been produced by the Council.

The NHS handed down its final report in December 1992, Agenda for Action, with recommendations for a national strategy. The NWCC's involvement was important in the final outcome and has meant women's concerns are incorporated in the national strategy.

The video is being used as a educative tool in the Health and Community Centre and it will be used to make a Community announcement suitable for television production.

A report on the findings of the research has now been finalised and covers rehabilitation programs currently used by employers, differences between private and Commonwealth rehabilitation schemes, preventative measures in the workplace and the different forms of rehabilitation to assist NESB women to return to the work force. PARA.TAB: The Working Party, in conjunction with the Australian Film Commission (AFC), produced the Report What do I Wear for a Hurricane? Women in Australian Film, Television, Video and Radio Industries. The Report provides a comprehensive statistical analysis of survey results conducted to examine industry employment for women. Recommendations from the Report aim to facilitate greater equity for women in assessing training, entering the industry and successfully achieving their career goals.

ANSWER.PARA: Position Paper

PARA.TAB: The Working Party is producing a Position Paper which outlines issues relating to the portrayal of women in the media for general circulation.

ANSWER.PARA: Media Information Kit

PARA.TAB: The Working Party, through consultants Media Insight and Dr Shashi Wilson, are currently gathering together a substantial body of information addressing the portrayal of women in the media from which an information package will be produced for decision makers in the media. The Kit will include three types of information:
a content survey of television and newspaper news and current affairs;
a statistical description of women's educational, workforce and lifestyle experiences; and
a survey of currently available primary research regarding attitudes to the portrayal of women in the media.

The aim of the kit is to provide information to people in decision making positions which is likely to affect in a positive manner their decisions regarding portrayal of women, broaden their conceptions of women as an audience or market and inform them of issues of concern to women. The kit will be launched at an industry forum in June.

ANSWER.PARA: Communicating to Women in the 1990s—a one day workshop for people in advertising

PARA.TAB: A one day workshop for people in advertising titled Communicating to Women in the 1990s was attended by over 130 people in Sydney on 30 April 1990. The then Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women the Hon Wendy Fatin launched the Reference Directory at the close of the workshop.
The workshop was co-sponsored by the Working Party, Advertising Federation of Australia Ltd, and the Australian Association of National Advertisers.

The aim of the day was to have respected people from the advertising industry speaking to members of the industry. Key sessions have been included in the video component of the Women and Advertising A Resource Package.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Prime Minister and Cabinet: Media Releases

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the department routinely disseminate or circulate all or some of the media releases of its responsible Minister or Ministers, to organisations apart from national media organisations; if so, for what reasons are Ministerial media releases circulated by the department, and to how many individuals or organisations.

(2) For each, and which, Ministerial media release circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the releases, and how many copies of the release were circulated.

(3) Does the department circulate copies of some or all of the speeches made by the Minister, if so, for each of those circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the speech and how many copies of the speech were circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, my Department does distribute some media releases to individuals and organisations other than national media organisations. These releases are distributed on behalf of my Press Office or a Minister Assisting in the area of responsibility to which the press release relates. Not all organisations and individuals receive all media releases. The media release mailing list is divided into categories e.g. environment, women, business etc with individuals and organisations receiving those releases relevant to their areas of interest. During the last 18 months 11 individuals and 1,384 organisations received media releases on various topics.

(2) During the last 18 months 211 media releases (26,818 copies) and 70 speeches (7,776 copies) were distributed. The cost of printing and circulating these releases and speeches amounted to $29,422. To list each release and speech with associated cost would be a major task and I am not prepared at this time to commit the resources necessary to detail this information. A list of major Prime Ministerial media releases and speeches is contained in the Department's Annual Report.
(3) Covered in (2).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 16 December 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has there been a call for an investigation into allegations of misuse of taxpayers' money by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) in the Goldfields region of Western Australia.

(2) Has ATSIC given almost $15000 from an Aboriginal Resource Agency's operating surplus to fund travel and accommodation expenses for a single bush meeting to be held in Kalgoorlie to discuss issues outside the Council's jurisdiction.
(3) Has the Wongi Regional Council refused to disclose to their own members how and where Aboriginal funding has been spent.
(4) Is there an unresolved dispute between the Wongi and the Gubrun people over traditional lands.
(5) Will an investigation be conducted into the allegations raised in (1), (2) and (3).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, Mr Gary Boyle, who was the endorsed Liberal Party candidate for the State seat of Kalgoorlie has called for an investigation.

(2) Approval was granted for the Eastern Goldfields Aboriginal Corporation Resource Agency to use $14580 of a 1991-92 grant surplus for a bush meeting which was held on 14 and 15 December. ATSIC's programming delegations require the delegate to have Council support before approving the use of surplus funds, for which a majority supported the action. It was not a case of the matter being outside Council's jurisdiction.

(3) No. The Wongi Regional Council has published information concerning its administrative expenditure and program expenditure under its area of responsibility in its 1991/92 Annual report and also regularly includes information in its newsletter concerning which organisations received endorsement for funding under the various ATSIC programs.
(4) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 30 March 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Department routinely disseminate or circulate all or some of the media releases of its responsible Minister or Ministers, to organisations apart from the national media organisations; if so, for what reasons are Ministerial media releases circulated by the department, and to how many individuals or organisations.

(2) For each, and which, Ministerial media release circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the releases, and how many copies of the release were circulated.

(3) Does the department circulate copies of some or all of the speeches made by the Minister; if so, for each of those circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the speech and how many copies of the speech were circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) does not disseminate or circulate Ministerial media releases.
(2) Nil.

(3) The Commission does not regularly circulate copies of speeches made by the Minister. Over the past 18 months, four of the Minister's speeches were included in publications produced and distributed by ATSIC. These were:
a speech, which was included in a booklet with a range of other speeches, to mark the 25th anniversary of the 1967 Referendum. 5000 copies have been distributed.
Three speeches to the UN working Group on Indigenous populations, which were included in a booklet which contained all of the Australian contributions. 5000 copies have been circulated.
The costs are unable to be estimated as they were included in the overall costs of the two publications.
The Commission is satisfied that there is no basis to the allegations in questions (1), (2) and (3) and therefore will not be conducting an investigation.
